the talisman that exorcises pestilence spirits and saves lives—
is of great power.
You and your disciples must observe the world:
if any are afflicted, treat them urgently.
The people fear this sickness greatly,
yet few can cure it.
When they see their lives saved, they will rejoice,
praising the marvelous efficacy—
worthy of Heaven’s hearing.
All sins of bodily obstruction shall be erased.
Guard this treasure carefully—do not reveal it to the unworthy.*

*Before Master Zhang Daoling practiced this method,
when Chinese people sought treatment from foreign masters,
those who went perished with their entire households—
not even minor exorcisms could save them.*

*Note: In the past, a third-generation foreign master entered China
and attempted to exorcise this spirit.
The spirit resisted,
and its qi struck him down.
This is fully recorded in *The Flowing Pearl: Middle Section*—
no need to repeat it here.*

*The pestilence spirit’s *eye* is located on the left hand’s fourth finger, third joint.
To the right of the joint, near the fingernail,
lies the *pestilence spirit’s blade*—
if struck, the spirit dies within three days.
This is highly verified.*

*In antiquity, Zuo Ci, styled Yuanfang, of Jiangdong,
was skilled in restraining spirits.
When Wei Wen Di heard of him, he commanded the exorcism of pestilence spirits.
The spirits, weeping, said to one another:
‘The Jiangdong Master Zuo will pinch our eyes with copper claws—
we must leave.
If we do not, he will strike us with his blade—
we will die immediately.’
They wept and departed together.
Within three days, all illnesses in the palace vanished,
the healthy remained untainted,
and none contracted the sickness.*

*The Most High Lord Lao bestowed the *Eight Barbarian Scriptures*,
which contain talismanic officials to subdue spirits.
Preserve them as in the diagram—
the pestilence spirits will flee.
If they do not flee, they will die.
This is highly verified."*

The fifth *yin* virtue: The Most High Lord Lao said: *"Those who cultivate the Dao with a focused mind must take compassion as their foundation, rescuing and delivering all beings as their primary purpose, and subduing evil while establishing the rectified qi as their intent. If there is evil, the rectified qi cannot flow or descend. If one can employ talismans and medicines to treat malevolent spirits without harming the rectified, then even those whose hearts are steeped in evil may be given one or two talismans to swallow and purify them. For those afflicted with chronic evil illnesses—lingering, dim-witted, and enfeebled for ten or five years—these are the spirits of old *lao* (precocious) ghosts and demons, fox, weasel, or rat *jing* (essence-spirits). They may be pursued and beheaded with talismans without hesitation. Saving one person earns one virtue; exterminating a spirit earns two virtues.

The method for extermination involves reciting the *Di Ji* (Earth Memorization) once and the *Fei Tian Gang* (Flying Heaven Rope) once. Then, perform the *Yu Bu* (Flood Step) nine times, align with the *Pei Yi* (Configuring Garment) of the Seven Stars, turn the *Tian Guan* (Heavenly Lock), and point toward a specific village or household in a certain place. With three six nines (27) finger-pointings, summon the Six Generals of the Middle and Lower *Yuan* (Origins) to that person’s residence, commanding them to unleash water and fire, leading three hundred million troops as depicted in the diagram. If the Three Generals of the Middle *Yuan* are invoked from the *Liu Zhu Zhong Wai Pian* (Flowing Pearl Inner and Outer Chapters), they will arrive at the door to capture and exterminate the ghost, circling the residence with a great shout. Often, after three such invocations, the spirit will die, and the illness will abate. This *yin* virtue is also great, and the world will revere it.*

The sixth *yin* virtue: When a practitioner’s cultivation is complete, they may sit and rescue those thousands of miles away. With a talisman, they can save people in battle, binding it to a person’s body to ward off blades and swords, preventing harm. On a *Liu Jia* (Six Jia) day, one may invoke the *Liu Jia* deities, take three steps of the *Yu Bu* (nine traces), align with the *Pei Yi*, and point three times with the hand. This grants the *Xing Jun Huo Fu* (Marching Army Fire Talisman) and the *Dai Jue* (Bound Avoidance), ensuring the wearer will never be harmed by bandits. If a great general seeks to annihilate enemy forces for the state, they may be given the *Wan Sheng Shen Fu* (Ten-Thousand Victory Divine Talisman) to bind, rendering blades and swords powerless to harm.

For those commanding armies to strengthen the state, one may recite the *Di Ji* nine times, the *Fei Tian Gang* three times, disperse the *Yu Bu* in nine traces three times, twelve traces three times, and fifteen traces three times. Then align with the *Pei Yi*, turn the *Tian Guan*, and point toward the enemy’s direction nine times, pinching the *dao zhi* (claw support) of the person in that direction.
*Note: If the enemy is in the East (Wood), use the Wood-person *dao zhi*; West (Metal), Metal-person *dao zhi*; South (Fire), Fire-person *dao zhi*; North (Water), Water-person *dao zhi*; Seasons (Earth), Earth-person *dao zhi*. Alternatively, one may also correspond with the Five Phases (Metal, Water, Wood, Fire, Earth) as needed.*

These two methods are the same. Additionally, sprinkle water in accordance with the direction, and the enemy will self-destruct. This method must be kept secret and not used recklessly. The ancient sage-kings revealed this method to save those who cultivate the Dao, aiding them in times of difficulty and assisting Daoist states in peril. It must not be used lightly—without proper mandate, even a moment’s misuse is forbidden.

The ancient sage-kings further instructed: *"Realgar of a red hue—write the two *Da Jie* (Great Calamity) talismans, which are detailed in the *Li Fa* (Ritual Method). Also write the *Ru Jun Fu* (Entering Army Talisman) and the six *Liu Jia Yin Fu* (Six Jia Yin Talismans), binding them to the soldiers. In battle, they will suffer no injury for every ten thousand. These talismans are found in the *Liu Zhu Zhong Wai Pian* military methods."*

The seventh *yin* virtue: If the heavens endure prolonged rain without ceasing, and floods devastate the people—drowning villages, towns, and individuals—one may, in secret at night, recite the *Di Ji* three times and the *Fei Tian Gang* three times. Then disperse into the *Yu Bu* of nine traces, reaching twelve and fifteen traces, align with the *Pei Yi*, turn the *Tian Guan*, and point three times toward the darkest clouds. After three repetitions, issue a talisman to the local shrine, stipulating a specific day and hour for the rain to cease. If it does, pinch the *Long Mu* (Dragon’s Eye).
*Note: The eye is on the left side of the second joint of the left hand’s index finger, near the claw nail. Pinch it urgently.*

The eighth *yin* virtue: If the heavens withhold rain for too long, caused by the *Kang Long* (Proud Dragon), and crops wither and die—unless this drought is a heavenly decree—
*Note: If the drought is a heavenly command, do not act recklessly, lest you harm the Dragon’s mandate. The heavens punish the Dragon, and retribution follows naturally.*

If the drought is caused by the *Tu Di Long Shen* (Earthly Land Dragon Spirit) refusing to rain, one may, at night in an unoccupied courtyard, recite the *Di Ji* and *Fei Tian Gang* each three times, disperse into the *Yu Bu* of three steps and nine traces three times, align with the *Pei Yi*, turn the *Tian Guan*, and point three times toward a deep pool.
*Note: The pool must contain dragons or water deities, the officials of the Water Palace, to ensure immediate efficacy and swift rain as urgent as fire.*

At dawn, write the *Zhi Ri Fu* (Direct Day Talisman) and the *Jiu Long Shui Fu* (Nine Dragons Water Talisman), affixing them to the local shrine and land gods.
*Note: In ancient times, there were no *Cheng Huang* (City Gods); today, one must first invoke the City God officials and the land boundary shrine and water palace spirit officials, along with the Direct Day deity, to assemble the assembly and command the rain to fall at the appointed time. Urgently, as the law decrees. The deities will swiftly cause the rain to fall within the stipulated days, nourishing all rivers and streams, fulfilling the oath of hand and mouth.*

The Most High Lord Lao said: *"I have transmitted this method to the world, so that those who cultivate the Dao may save others and achieve great merit. Those who save all under heaven will attain peace and joy beyond measure. This virtue is unfathomable, and those who uphold it will ascend the ranks of the immortals. This eighth virtue is what all sages and true ones have long kept in mind for those who earnestly study. Mastering this method and accumulating merit leads directly to the Dao.

The later sage-kings further transmitted the three *Long Fu* (Dragon Talismans), including the second method of the *Liu Jia Lu* (Six Jia Scriptures) and the talisman of the *Zhi Ri Shen* (Direct Day Deity)."*

「Annotation: Within the *Six Jia Scriptures*, the method is selected as follows: One talisman is used to summon the Dragon Talismans, in accordance with the law, swiftly as water and fire. The Dragon Talisman is invoked by the *Long Jue* (Dragon Decision), located on the left hand’s second finger at its first joint.

The Most High Lord Lao said: *"Those who earnestly cultivate the Dao and seek verification must first understand this method of employing the Way to subdue dragons and enslave ghosts. Those who fail to grasp it will drift ever farther from the Dao, and must not presume to practice it. This method aids and assists the human body. I observe that in the present age, those who study the Dao merely take sound and image as the Dao.

Annotation: The wind carries the teachings of the ancient *Wu Wei* (Non-Action) Dao; now, they have entered the realm of *You Wei* (Action).

Nowadays, when people hear the Dao’s teachings, their ears and eyes are filled with devotion, and when they see its symbols, their hearts and spirits rise in faith. Though they may briefly awaken to goodness, their actions do not align with the Dao’s source, nor with the Dao itself. They merely labor at constructing mountains of merit that span the skies, only to exhaust themselves in vain and dissipate their efforts. Thus, the truly wise do not take sound and image as their instruction.

This is the hollow merit of the petty-minded, who vainly practice in the world. To recognize one’s true nature as *virtue* (德),—

Annotation: Lord Lao’s words here instruct the students, stating that in the present age, people mistake the forced cultivation of knowledge and true nature as the heart of *You Wei* (Action) virtue, rather than the natural virtue of *Wu Wei* (Non-Action). Throughout their lives, they exhaust themselves in futile, arduous striving. Such people, though the world may count them by the ten-thousand, will not achieve a single success. I often lament this, hence I have left ten conditions of hidden merit, and this is the foremost.

In the time of the ancient sage-king Shun, there was a drought lasting one hundred days. The emperor commanded his ministers to pray for rain. After fifty days, the sun’s midday heat scorched people with thirst and want, and many died—spread across all nine regions, with mountains blazing, grasses withering, and stones glowing like embers, making it unbearable for people to stand. Suddenly, two immortals arrived, and one sighed: *"What kind of people are these, finding joy in such agonizing heat? Why?"*

The other replied: *"Let us pray for rain to descend."*

The immortal said: *"Rain is the dragon’s movement; why should it concern your prayers?"*

The official answered: *"We pray that the dragon descends and moves to bring rain."*

The immortal asked: *"Do you recognize the dragon?"*

The official said: *"I recognize it."*

The immortal then said: *"Since you recognize the dragon, where is it? Why do you pray for its rain?"*

At this, the officials knelt in unison, asking the immortal to indicate the dragon’s whereabouts. The immortal suddenly pointed at one man’s foot, and the dragon moved with tiger-like strides—

Annotation: The act of pointing with the hand is the turning of the Celestial Gate.

The man’s foot became the dragon’s and tiger’s steps, resembling the *Wu Bu* (Avoiding Steps) of today. After three strides, the immortal shouted: *"Why does the dragon not move to bring rain?"*

At that moment, the dragon bowed and said: *"The Celestial Sovereign forbids rain for one hundred and eighty days. I have already twice secretly brought rain to save people, but both times I was summoned by the Underworld to report. This time, I dare not move, for if I do, I will be summoned, and my transgression will be heard by the Supreme Deity. The Celestial Talisman will descend to punish my body as a dragon."*

The immortal immediately sought paper and brush, writing a Celestial Talisman decree. He affixed it to the shrine deities and the dragon, commanding them to bring rain together. At that time, the shrine deities and the dragon, having received the decree, brought rain as ordered, and the limit was fulfilled within one day.

Annotation: Though the limit was fulfilled within one day, this method is too harsh. The dragon and deities, in their urgency to bring rain, must use violent winds and torrential downpours, uprooting trees. The immortal’s original intent was to secretly bring rain, but fearing that the Celestial Sovereign might forbid it and assign all the blame to the dragon, he ordered the storm to be swift. If the Celestial Sovereign did not punish the dragon, it would be spared. If he did punish it, the immortal feared damage to the dragon. At that time, the dragon was not punished, which was due to the immortal’s compassion, saving all beings in the world. Thus, the Celestial Sovereign did not blame the dragon. Instead, he rewarded the shrine deities, the dragon deities, and the eight departments of the river and sea spirits, granting them promotions. From then on, all of them thanked the immortal one by one.

Now, if one obtains this method, the rain limit is set within three to five days, and this is already considered a great merit. Both the deities and the people rejoice, and according to the limit, the rain will be fulfilled, and promotions will follow. The merit’s efficacy lies with the Daoist master, who assesses the merit and may bestow rewards of wine and music.

Later, there are three *Hui* (Assembly) days, where separate offerings are made to declare the merit’s efficacy.

Annotation: There is a method that does not require offerings; one simply submits the merit declaration and petition. This is not permissible. The three Assembly days are the days of the grand *Jiao* (Offering), when one must set up generals, officials, and soldiers, as if the world’s emperor commands his vassals and ministers, overseeing the three armies in a similar manner. Each year, these rites must be performed in spring and winter; failure to do so violates the imperial command. This is the *San Yuan Lu* (Three Primordial Scriptures), which takes the Three Primordial days for the offering, along with one petition and merit declaration. It is not necessary to submit all petitions and documents, lest they trouble the Supreme Deity and Lord of the Dao.

The ninth condition of hidden merit: The Most High Lord Lao instructed the male *Zhen Ren* (True Persons) like *Zhen Wang* (True King) Fang Ping and Han Fei Zheng, and the female *Zhen Ren* like Li the Lady, Wang the Lady, and the Lady of *Zi Wei* (Purple Micro), among the seventy-two great *Zhen Ren*, saying: *"In the world, those who earnestly cultivate hidden merit must strive for the greatest deeds—none surpass saving people and aiding the poor, nor honoring the spirits of the dead and repairing tombs.

Annotation: The honoring of tombs refers to the ancient Yellow Emperor, who during his inspection of Mount Tai encountered a buried corpse whose coffin had been washed away by water, causing the earth to collapse and expose thousands of skeletal remains. The emperor, moved by the suffering of the common people, had them all collected and placed between four large boards, with the space taken from an uninhabited highland and buried in a deep pit. He then built a mound of earth three feet high, naming it a *fen* (tomb). After this, people followed the Yellow Emperor’s example. This burial method involved four large boards, isolating the four sides of the earth, and one large board placed above as a cover—this was the method of constructing tombs. Even to this day, people use coffins as boards and *guo* (outer coffins), adding new embellishments and calling them *mu* (graves).

In his dreams, the emperor saw over a thousand people come to thank him, saying: *"Your Majesty governs the living with the Dao and the dead with virtue. Now, we, your subjects—over a thousand seven hundred in number—have been granted your celestial mercy. You provided shelter for our exposed bones, and we have already yesterday petitioned the Celestial Bureau, stating that we were blessed by your Majesty’s mercy in relocating and burying our remains. The Bureau has rewarded your Majesty’s deeds with double merit."*」

From this point onward, forty-five years passed, and the sun ascended into the clouds of heaven by day—he was indeed to become a supreme true immortal. Later, as foretold, he attained divine communion.

**Annotation:** *Huangdi’s Original Chapter* records the method of erecting tombs and burying the dead to teach the world. When people learned this, their merit spread across the world, delighting gods and ghosts. After death, some with strong and wise spirits became celestial deities, earth deities, deities of the soil, or deities of grain, while the weaker became ghosts. Among ghosts, there were three ranks: superior, middle, and inferior.

The superior ghosts bestow blessings upon the virtuous and repay human kindness. The middle ghosts neither bless nor harm. These two ranks, if they attain rebirth early, are called *shan gui* (benevolent ghosts) in the retribution of human and heavenly realms. The Most High cherished them, forbidding those who received Daoist precepts from harming them, lest they lose the path to heavenly rebirth.

The inferior ghosts, however, constantly bring calamity, misfortune, and disease to the world. The Most High and the Sage Lords were enraged and often commanded Daoists to subdue and exterminate them with spells. Once subjected to Daoist judgment, their spirits were bound to the Northern Emperor’s dark and desolate peaks, imprisoned for years without resolution. Even if released, they could not be reborn as humans. Only those judged by the *Huai Tian* (Mars) were condemned to be reborn as venomous creatures—centipedes, scorpions, and snakes—dying a hundred times before being reborn once, never again as humans.

When the human realm rejoiced, the hundred rivers and spiritual beasts presented auspicious diagrams, while the four seas’ dragons offered pearls and jade—was this not the virtue and divine communion of the Emperor’s hidden deeds?

Again, the Celestial Worthy instructed the ascetic practitioners of bitter austerity, such as Guo Jinqing, saying: *"Your austerities save others, none greater than sowing merit. Its fruits will benefit future generations. I grant you treasures and firewood when you are in need—such deeds are vast and verifiable, leading to the Dao."*

Moreover, he taught the forging of copper and iron into counterfeit gold and silver, taking only half the price—**Annotation:** *Half the price* means that genuine gold is worth ten *guan* per *liang* (ounce), but since counterfeit gold is made of copper or iron, one *liang* could be sold for half its value, yielding 2,500 in profit per *liang*. Yet even this, the Sage Lords permitted only for the practitioner’s own sustenance—clothing, food, and household needs—and forbade reckless excess. This method was taught by the Sage Lords of old and new to those on the Daoist path, allowing them to provide for themselves and their families.

Moreover, they also used cloth and silk to make garments, feigning lost clothing along the way to give alms to the poor and the sick, thereby seeking the hidden virtue of *yin-de* (meritorious deeds unseen by others). In the past, several *zhenren* (perfected ones) practiced such deeds. This provided for their own families while also rescuing the poor and the sick—another great merit.

One must not deceive the world by falsely claiming such actions as true gold, nor should one exploit the faithful by inflating the value of treasures and rare artifacts to mislead honest people. Such crimes are grave and cannot be redeemed by seeking hidden merit. **Beware.**

**Annotation:** In the past, *Yin Changsheng* (a Daoist adept) would feign lost money to aid the destitute, thereby earning hidden merit through such deeds. Today, some falsely claim this Daoist method, deceiving common folk by saying, *"This forged gold, when refined, becomes an elixir—unmatched in the world, worthy of immortals’ alchemy."* Yet how could immortals engage in such worldly deceit?

Furthermore, immortals all practice methods of lightening the body, allowing them to transcend physical form at will. They consume elixirs of metals and minerals to achieve levitation—such claims are utterly baseless.

**The Tenth Principle of *Yin-Function* (Hidden Merit):**
A discourse on how *zhenren* (perfected ones) and their disciples practice hidden merit and its virtues.

---
*End of the Eighteenth Section: "The Golden Lock and Flowing Pearl Introduction"*

「The **Grand Daoist Sage** of the **Central Realm**, **Zaiwang** of the **Great Perfection**, **Zhang Daoling**, **Zhao Sheng**, **Wang Chang** (the **Master of Command**), **Li Zhongfu**, **Mao Ying**, **Xu Yufu**, and others, were all later disciples who compiled and expounded upon the teachings. The **Daoist Sage** **Li Chunfeng** annotated them. Below, the **Six Jia** (注: *Six Jia* refers to the six celestial stems, 甲,乙,丙,丁,戊,己, symbolizing a cycle of Daoist practices) **Yin-Function** (Hidden Merit) is discussed.

**Old Lord** (注: *Old Lord*, 老君, refers to **Laozi**, the revered Daoist sage and patriarch) instructed **Donglai Zi** (注: *Donglai Zi*, 東來子, is **Yu the Great’s** son):

*"Donglai Zi, you learned the Dao but did not practice **Yin-Function** (Hidden Merit), only **Yang-Function** (Manifest Virtue). Your craftsmanship was clever and refined—you built a tower in an empty wilderness, carving images of Daoist figures upon it, intending this as your lifelong virtue. You sought to rely on these merits to attain the Dao and transcendence. You claim that I have crafted over ten thousand merits for you, sufficient to make you a **Great Sage** (大仙).

One day, suddenly, two **Ming Officials** (注: *Ming Officials*, 二冥使, are underworld judges or messengers) summoned you to the **Gate of Tai Mountain** (太山門下), questioning why you constructed the tower, slaughtered living beings, and sacrificed them to spirits and ghosts in the rivers and wilds—countless oxen, pigs, sheep, donkeys, and other beasts. They said to you: *'Confess your crimes, or we shall bind your body and interrogate you further.'*

You replied: *'I submit to my transgressions and accept the blame for others.'* Then, I pardoned your offense.

But if you had not submitted, you would have been bound and punished. Your father had merit for managing the waters, now you are a **Tai Ji Perfected One** (太極真人), and cannot be cursed to bear the sin of killing. I shall reduce your father’s blessings to atone for your salvation, allowing you to return to the mortal world. If you now practice **Yin-Function** (Hidden Merit) to an extent surpassing others’ lifespans, you shall attain **perfected humanity** (成人), and for countless kalpas and lifetimes, you will no longer be sought by the underworld for retribution.

**Donglai Zi** responded: *'I submit.'*

Upon completion, the **Ming Official** truly consulted with **Tai Mountain Lord** (太山君), who released you from death, and you revived after seven days.

Afterward, you always acted with sincerity, never harming living beings. You frequently used your own wealth to redeem the lives of the deceased, liberating them without limit. You often did this.

Or, when people were imprisoned and bound, you would joyfully release them. Or, you would give food and clothing to those in jail.

For thirty years, those you had previously killed—oxen, sheep, pigs, donkeys, horses, and other livestock—all took rebirth as humans, forever free of resentment.

Because of these minor merits, you were favored by **Tai Shang Laozi** (太上老君), who revealed the **true teachings of Yin-Function** (Hidden Merit) to you, instructing you in the **steps of the Dao’s celestial principles** (天地纲纪之法) and granting you the **Six Jia merits** (六甲之功).

One day, suddenly, your **divine influence** (通神威) resonated with the heavens and earth, startling both mortals and immortals. **Old Lord** descended again, bestowing upon you the **Great Yin-Function** (大阴功).

You said: *'I have always been fond of constructing towers and altars, killing living beings to sacrifice to spirits and ghosts, intending this as a means to refine my body and seek the Dao.'*

*(As recounted earlier.)*

Now that the **Ming Officials** have informed you, you must reflect and repent. I shall now properly instruct you in **Yin-Function** (Hidden Merit). There are ten merits:

1. **Wearing the Six Jia True Talisman** (服六甲真符) to heal bodily ailments.
2. **True-heartedness** (真心), not causing harm or injury, not killing or wounding, not acting deceitfully or lustfully. *(注: Even if you have wives and concubines, do not arbitrarily change or defile others.)*
3. **Avoiding falsehood, flattery, and theft**, abandoning the nine levels of evil and cultivating the nine levels of good.
   - *One: Benevolence (慈),*
   - *Two: Filial piety (孝),*
   - *Three: Reverence in heart (心有敬),*
   - *Four: Dignity in form (身有礼),*
   - *Five: Practicing virtue (行仁德),*
   - *Six: Sparing speech (少言语),*
   - *Seven: Not acting before others (不为人之先).*
     - *Even if you are greater than others, you must yield and let them act first, so as not to diminish your own virtue (德).*
   - *Eight: Not harming spirits and ghosts unjustly (不妄害鬼神),*
   - *Nine: Always cherishing the Dao (常怀学道).*
4. **After attaining the Dao**, saving all beings.

*(注: **Yan Qing** (昔嚴清) once reduced the weight of charcoal by three or four coins per measure when selling it to the poor, or gave one or two measures to those in need. For over thirty years, one day a **Jade Maiden** (玉女) descended to bestow ten volumes of talismans and scriptures, beginning with the **Six Jia**. She commanded **Yan Qing** to kneel and receive them, explaining each one and teaching him to cultivate the **Six Jia Talismans**. **Yan Qing** replied: *'I do not understand scriptures.'* The **Jade Maiden** said: *'You already understand the nine levels of Yin-Function (Hidden Merit), so why not study and learn to recognize the characters? Once you grasp the scriptures, you will succeed.'*

Thus, **Yan Qing** began reading history books. Though he did not recognize the characters, the **Jade Maiden** taught him. Unable to write, she taught him calligraphy. In three years, he mastered the scriptures, filling his mind with knowledge, and none could question him—he was a sage. He frequently practiced the merit of healing the people’s illnesses and passed this on to his disciples, who all took healing as their practice. At the time, it was called **Yan Jun’s Dao** (嚴君之道).

Later, the **Holy Sage** (聖君) informed the **Heavenly Master** (天師):

*'You instruct your disciples in practicing Yin-Function (Hidden Merit), which has two essentials:*
   - *(注: One, the teacher must discern the disciple’s sincerity; two, the disciple must be filial to the teacher.)*
   - *One: The teacher must first discern the disciple—whether they have sincerity or not, faith or not. *(注: In this age, many disciples have empty words but no sincerity. Such people must not be lightly trusted to pass on teachings.)* You must weigh their sincerity carefully; do not hastily judge them. If you judge them accurately, the teacher will not err, and you may then impart a minor stage of the Dao’s methods. If the disciple has a resolute heart and delights in the Dao, day and night thinking of the Dao and rejoicing in its truth, earnestly offering supplies, the teacher will measure their deeds according to the scriptures, reducing their faults to guide them in practicing Yin-Function (Hidden Merit).*
   - *Two: The disciple must always know the teacher’s sincerity is true and upright, secretly invoking the Dao to honor the teacher. The teacher, in turn, will be moved and often reveal themselves to the disciple. The disciple will call upon the teacher, and the teacher will respond in their heart and mind, fulfilling all their deeds—except for the three rebellions. *(注: One, not rebelling against the sovereign’s words; two, not rebelling against the father’s instructions; three, not rebelling against the teacher’s guidance.)* These three prohibitions are the **Heavenly Master’s** instructions to **Wang Chang** and **Zhao Sheng**, passed on to disciples.*

*Again, the **Heavenly Master** said: 'He who secretly guides others to attain the Dao’s highest truths and honors, is said to have a **heart of benevolent enlightenment** (心願啓善利人), known as **Yin-Function** (Hidden Merit), and as **practicing Yin-Virtue** (行阴德). The heavens reward such deeds, and their descendants will inherit this virtue through generations, never ceasing to hold official positions. *(注: If you guide others in good deeds—such as healing illnesses, delivering them from calamities and misfortunes—always act with sincerity, never committing evil, and frequently practice benevolence to save the nation and people, then your merits will be fulfilled, and you will ascend to immortality in broad daylight.)*'*

If one secretly guides others toward evil, harming people and things, even if they guide them to the Dao’s highest truths and honors, it will never truly prevail. If they secretly guide others to act harmfully, damaging people and things, this is called **Yin-Plotting**, and is known as **practicing Yin-Treason** (行阴贼). The heavens abhor such deeds, and their descendants will surely suffer early deaths. *(Note: Even if descendants do not perish, they will still suffer illness, holding no office nor rank, and will be commoners.)*

I now pass this teaching to you again, knowing you must act as a substitute teacher and instruct future generations. Do not harbor evil intentions—always speak with benevolence. *(Note: Benevolent speech is the voice of teaching; benevolent intentions are the heart’s practice.)* Benevolent intentions are supreme.

**The *Six Jia Ling Shu* (Sacred Scriptures of the Six Jia) – Yang-Merits**
There is also the *Six Jia Ling Shu*, which expounds on **yang-merits**, comprising ten sections.
Here, the ten precepts are briefly recorded. *[Note: Fully elaborated in *The Transmission of the Venerable Lord*.]*

1. **Broadly gathering causes and conditions**, assembling congregations, constructing earthen and wooden pavilions and halls—accumulating merits numbering in the ten-thousands—this is called **yang-merit**, uncounted among the yin.
   The **Sage Sovereign** said: Such a person, in a future life, will become an official, possess wealth and grand halls, with prosperous descendants yet no noble status.

2. **Observing fasts and reciting scriptures**, accumulating merits numbering in the ten-thousands—this is called **yang-merit**, uncounted among the yin.
   The **Lord** said: In a future life, one will be endowed with wisdom, with clear and upright ears and eyes, having virtuous sons and daughters who are filial, and attaining official rank.

3. **Exhorting others to do good**, prompting almsgiving, and donating wealth numbering in the ten-thousands—this too is **yang-merit**, uncounted among the yin.
   The **Lord** said: In a future life, one will become a leader among people, the chief of those who consume flesh, with descendants inheriting this status across generations.

4. **Acting with sincere devotion and labor**, broadly constructing earthen and wooden structures, erecting frameworks for halls and temples, and rigorously clearing mountain paths—this too is **flourishing merit**, uncounted among the yin.
   The **Lord** said: In a future life, one will be reborn as a male, holding an official position with wealth, slaves, and servants at their command, with prosperity lasting two generations—yet afterward, one’s station will decline. The **Great Dao forbids such ambition**.

5. **Casting and crafting bells and statues**, completing the merit of becoming an immortal—where statues manifest the transient goodness of mortals—this too is **yang-merit**, uncounted among the yin.
   The **Lord** said: In a future life, one will be skilled in song and music, with a well-proportioned body, yet lacking in wealth and sustenance.

6. **Reciting incantations idly**, invoking them loudly and calling out to chastise ghosts and spirits—even if it saves a person—this is **yang-merit**.
   The **Lord** told the **Celestial Master**: Though this merit is not fully attained, it still emerges from the body, yet because the chastisement is excessive, in a future life one will suffer few illnesses but lack descendants.

7. **Digging wells along roads and rivers**, providing water and gruel—this too is **yang-merit**.
   Though this act benefits others, it aligns with **yin-speech of merit**, as it is said, *"So-and-so dug this well."*
   The **Lord** said: Such a person’s descendants will receive half of the yin-merit, while the individual attains yang-merit, transforming into benevolent deeds that aid those in urgent need.

8. **Leveraging official authority or borrowed strength to rescue others from罪**, this too is **yang-merit**.
   The **Lord** said: In a future life, one will receive blessings, or perhaps reap rewards in this very life—this is the merit of **auspicious yang**.

9. **Constructing bridges and causeways**, facilitating passage and transit—this too is **yang-merit**.
   The **Lord** said: In a future life, one will constantly benefit from the kindness of travelers.

10. **Receiving ordination and taking vows**, with a pure mind and spirit, abstaining from marriage, and dwelling in high mountains—this too is **yang-merit**.
   The **Lord** said: In a future life, one will attain the Dao of **non-action**.

The above corresponds to a full year of twelve months, each with thirty days. One must align the individual’s **native star** with the day’s constellation, beginning from the first day and concluding on the thirtieth. Each month’s sequence is matched accordingly.

The **Supreme Primordial Lord Laozi**, having received instruction from the **Primordial Dao Lord Yuan Shi**, recorded this as the *Scripture of the Twenty-Eight Constellations*, comprising twelve volumes and two hundred sheets—its vastness making it difficult to fully explore.

Now, this abridged version of the *Twenty-Eight Constellations Scripture* is compiled to correspond with the thirty days of each month, demonstrating how to correlate and observe one’s **native star** to discern prosperity or decline.

Thus, the **Edict of Edging Through** is condensed into essential principles, teaching humanity to record and reflect upon it.

The **Supreme Primordial Lord Laozi** declared:
*"For those cultivating longevity, knowing one’s **native star**—the constellation governing one’s birth—is paramount. The **wandering star** is the constellation of one’s life’s destiny.

If the **native star** aligns perfectly in its proper position, yet a **wandering star** intrudes upon it, this is most malevolent, bringing great calamity. If only the **wandering star** intrudes, the consequences are lighter.

These two matters must be carefully observed: if the star is bright, misfortune will not befall; if it is dim, illness and disaster will arise. One must act swiftly, invoking talismans and rituals to dispel them, thereby eliminating sickness and averting decline.

On one’s **native star’s day**, if the night is clear, observe it secretly when no one is about. If it is bright and clear, it is auspicious; if dim or flickering, disaster is near; if unseen, great misfortune looms.

Then, recite the **Earth-Treading Step** and the **Heavenly Halter** each three times, perform the **Yugaitian Steps**, and turn the **Heavenly Pass**. Point toward the direction of the afflicted person’s **star of decline or ghostly abode**—for all are born into regions of calamity.

For instance, a **Metal-born** individual has:
- **Longevity** in **Si (Peril)**,
- **Bathing** in **Wu (Boiling)**,
- **Crowning** in **Wei (Encirclement)**,
- **Official Duty** in **Shen (Apply)**,
- **Sovereignty** in **You (Jade)**,
- **Decline** in **Xu (Empty)**,
- **Sickness** in **Hai (Hide)**,
- **Death** in **Zi (Self)**,
- **Tomb** in **Chou (Rest)**,
- **Ruination** in **Yin (Conceal)**,
- **Severance** in **Mao (Insult)**.

「Indeed, those who study with the resolve to follow the Dao must first comprehend this method, only then may they attain the true preservation of life.

If one does not understand the matters of decline and calamity, they will fall ill and die. This method can help people dispel disasters, overcome misfortunes, and ward off sickness, even saving relatives and Daoist companions.

The Central Palace belongs to **Earth**, and when Earth loses its position, it multiplies the harm done to all other directions, which people should not fail to recognize. Those who know this method may follow its principles, saving themselves first and then ten others.

But among the **Twenty-Eight Constellations**, each constellation governs countless billions of people beneath it. If one practices this method, they may save a hundred souls, yet the world remains unaware—how much more so for saving just one life or a few relatives and friends, who would still be saved. Yet people remain ignorant, openly receiving the **Ming** (dark) commands from the celestial agents, who come to summon them to death—this is truly a grievous fate!

Those dwelling at the edges of the heavens beneath the native star will also suffer hundreds or thousands of deaths.

Moreover, when the star is bright and clear, one need not perform the **步蹑 (Bujie)** steps or the **祭醮 (Jijiao)** rituals. If they do, they will instead invite disasters and calamities upon their entire household, not just themselves.

The **Laozi (Lao Jun)** has universally commanded this prohibition, and those in **white robes** (laypersons) do not accept it, while those who invert the Dao (false teachers) often allow the **天关 (Tian Guan)** agents to turn and point at the native stars of people.

To the **Incense Officials (香官)**, **messengers (使者)**,
The **Lords of the Left and Right Dragon-Tiger (左右龙虎君)**,
And the **attending Star Officials of the Incense (侍香诸灵官)**.

May this **jiào (醮)** summon forth:
**Golden Elixir, Lapis Lazuli, Immortal Mushrooms, and Sacred Herbs (金液丹碧芝英)**,
A gathering of **hundreds of True Ones and numinous spirits (众真百灵)**,
All convening before the incense and flames of this furnace.

May it grant me:
To **practice Dao and attain Dao (学道得道)**,
To **seek immortals and attain immortality (求仙得仙)**,
To bring blessings to my household,
To bestow grace upon all under heaven,
So that **ten thousand immortal children and jade maidens (十方仙童玉女)**,
Attending the **incense and smoke (香烟)**,
Convey my words directly to the **Supreme True Lord of the Boundless Dao, the Jade Sovereign of the Great Heavenly Emperor (至真无极玉皇大天帝)**.

Then, scatter the wine and food,
And immediately take the **tablets (简)**, step back,
Exit through the **Southern Angle (束南角)**,
First placing the right foot into the shoes,
Bow and farewell to the altar.

Next, recite the incantation:
*"From **yin** to **yang**, all matters open and flow.
The **Gate of Affairs (关启)** is now complete—
Prepare the **Palaces of the Immortals (仙宫)**."*

When finished, scatter the wine and food at will within the home,
Inviting the **twelve household deities (十二之神)**,
The **door wardens and gate guardians (门丞户尉)**,
The **generals of the dwelling (宅舍将军)**,
The **spirits of the well and hearth (井灶之神)**,
To partake and share in the feast.

May they also:
Array themselves in ranks to guard the home,
Prevent disasters from passing the door,
Avert epidemics from crossing the threshold,
Repel malevolent spirits and thieving ghosts,
So that none dare approach.

The **Great Dao’s sacred oath (大道盟威)** and the **Orthodox One’s secret precepts (正一秘法)**—
The matter is not trifling.
If you **guard and protect with merit (守镇有功)**,
And **promote blessings and assist in goodness (兴福助善)**,
On the **auspicious days of the Three Assemblies (三会吉日)**,
When the **ranked deities (同章)** are invoked for **transference (举迁)**,
Do not slacken—
Follow the law and **admonish or correct (弹纠)**,
Just as the **Heavenly Master’s statutes and commands (天师律令)** decree.

Scatter the wine and food.

If there is any sudden urgency,
Or matters of **illness or affliction (疾病事)**,
And you must **pray for resolution without delay (祈解一不可待)**—
Even if it concerns my **personal fate (本命)**—
Then use this day’s **ritual (此日)**.

**Miscellaneous Rituals for the Celestial Gate and National Protection, Household Safety, Bodyguard, Disaster Relief, and Human Salvation (杂使天关助国安家护身出灾度厄救人济物众法)**

**The Most High Lao Jun (太上老君)** says:
*"As for the **determined practitioner (志人)**—
All who **seek the Dao with resolve (志人学道)**,
Must always **devote their heart with diligence and caution (切心谨慎)**,
Serve their **master as their teacher (师事於师)**,
And **observe their master’s countenance (视师颜色)**,
Ever fearing their master will not teach them the **refined methods and precepts (妙用之法诀)**.

If they **obtain the precepts (得诀)**,
Their resolve is like **piercing stone (志若穿石)**—
They do not **shift their practice (不移习)**,
Nor **cease their transformation (不休转)**,
Even as the years deepen.
With **unwavering sincerity (至诚不退)**,
They are called **those who take the Dao with resolve (志心取道)**—
The Dao does not **fail such practitioners (道不负人)**.

Nowadays, people have **words without true hearts (有口无心)**,
Their **intentions are not sincere (用心不真)**,
And **without the Dao, they lack spirit (非道无神)**.
Yet **those who seek the Dao with resolve (修学志道)**** attain clarity (生明)**,
And **command the Seven Stars of the Northern Dipper (驱使七星北斗)**.

The **methods (法)** are for:
Aiding the nation, safeguarding the family,
Guarding the body, rescuing the sick,
Saving humans, benefiting all things,
And **communing with the spirits (通神)**.
Thus, **ten thousand soldiers cannot seize them (万兵不能执)**,
Nor **a hundred ghosts dare deceive them (百鬼不能欺)**,
**A thousand disasters vanish on their own (千灾自灭)**,
And **ten thousand calamities are powerless before them (万祸敢为)**—
They **enter water and fire without drowning or burning (入水入火，不溺不烧)**,
And **no realm of terror can measure their dread (惊畏之地莫测)**,
All **knowing it in advance (心皆预知)**.
They **communicate with spirits and attain divinity (通灵通神)**,
And **become immortals without doubt (成仙无疑)**—
Their **wishes are all fulfilled (所愿皆得)**.
Yet **these are not the acts of the determined practitioner (志人不为)**.

The **determined practitioner (志人)**,
With **earnest heart and longing for the Dao (心切慕道)**,
Does not **perform these methods (不为诸法)**,
Except to **rescue others from illness (救人疾病)**—
Then they **act without delay (之外不行)**."*

**The Orthodox One of Later Saints (后圣君)** says:
*"The **Dao’s messengers (大道之使者)**,
None surpass the **Central Dipper (中斗)**—
Below, mortals call it the **Northern Dipper (北斗)**.

It has **nine visible stars (九星)**,
And **two unseen stars (不见二星)**.
Always within the Dipper,
One star is named **Imperial Lord (帝尊)**—
This is the **recorder of virtues and sins (罚恶记善)**,
And the **master of all stars (万星之主)**.

The scriptures say:
*'The Central Dipper has nine stars,
Two stars unseen.
One star rules all celestial stars,
Serving the **Great Dao (大道)**,
Called **Imperial Lord (帝尊)**.*

But the **nine stars of the Nine Wilds (九野中星)**,
Excluding the **Five Elements and Six Yang stars (五行六甲大星)**,
Are all **Imperial Lord (帝尊)**’s single star’s **deputies (差为使)**—
Their **missions are very important (所主使也甚要)**.

The **First Star of Authority (执权一星)**,
Is named **Jade Sovereign (玉帝)**—
It **rules all stars and lodges between heaven and earth (主天地之间星宿)**,
The **heavenly deities and earthly spirits (天神地只)**,
**Human spirits, dragons, and ghosts (人神龙鬼)**,
And **malevolent spirits and deceitful deities (精邪奸祆)**—
All are under this **Star Lord’s command (此星君所部主也)**.

If one has **meritorious deeds toward heaven, earth, and living beings (善功於天地人物)**,
This **Star Lord** governs them all.
If one has **meritorious deeds toward heaven, earth, and living beings (善功於天地人物)**,
This **Star Lord** commands the **Celestial Gate’s messengers (天关使者)**,
To **open the gate and report (关奏)**,
And **petition the Jade Sovereign, the Great Dao’s Supreme Emperor (玉皇上帝道君)**,
So that **meritorious deeds are recorded (以善功立)**,
And **grades are promoted through repeated transference (数迁阶进品禄)**—
Not only **longevity and immortals (长生仙人)**,
But also **officials, generals, and common folk (世之官将人民)**,
All are under this **Star Lord’s governance (皆所主也)**.

If one commits **wicked and rebellious crimes (凶恶祆逆之罪)**,
This **Star Lord** also rules over them.
Thus, the **Celestial Gate’s messengers (天关使者)**,
According to the **lightness or gravity of the crime (随罪轻重)**,
May **demote or execute (贬杀)**.

The **Celestial Gate (天关)** is the **high commander (上将)**.
One star is named **Jade Sovereign Lord (玉帝君)**—
It **supervises the gate’s reporting (上主关奏)**,
And **petitions the Most High Boundless Dao Emperor (太上无极大道玉皇帝大道君)**.
Thus, all **Star Officials (众官)** call it the **Jade Sovereign Star Lord (玉帝星君)**.
As stated in the previous section.

**Lao Jun (老君)** says:
*"To **transform the Celestial Gate (转天关)**,
And **subdue the wicked and rebellious (伐凶逆)**,
And **aid the nation and safeguard the people (助国安人)**—
This is the **method (法)**."*

The **Star General** first enters with the **Military Tiger Talisman (兵虎符)** into the **Hall of Tranquility (靖室)**, stepping upon the **Earthly Stems (地纪)** in forward, reversed, and inverted sequences—each three times—then invoking the **Celestial Rope (飞天纲)** three times.
Forward, reversed, and inverted—each three times.
Upon completion, lower the Rope, disperse into **Yú’s Steps (禹步)**—three strides, nine traces—then reverse into twelve steps, and again into fifteen steps. Beneath the Rope, align with the **clothing talisman (配衣)**, the left hand seizing the **Military Talisman (出军符)** to **transform the Celestial Gate (转天关)**.
With the **Nine Fingers (九指)**, point at the **rebellious traitors of the realm (逆国贼)** and their cohorts. Shout their names—
If near, the voice is small; if many, adjust accordingly.
Then recite the incantation:
*"Wicked and rebellious [name], you rebel against the Sovereign,
Gathering demonic bands, stealing and plundering wealth,
Slaying innocent folk.
The Most High does not permit this—
Great evil, great wrath!
Command the **Celestial Gate’s messengers (勑消转斗关津)**,
Threefold with the Nine Fingers,
To annihilate [name]’s band—
All prohibitions, by oral decree, are now enforced.
I command my ministers to act—
Transform and subdue, kill.
As the Law decrees, swiftly."*

**Pinch the blade talisman (捻刀支诀)**, the formula aligned with the **Five Phases calculations (五方算)**—
*"Eastward, the Wooden Man’s blade talisman—so be it."*
Within one day, invoke the Nine Fingers three times.
Do not exceed one hundred days—
The traitors will self-destruct.
This method is **wondrously efficacious**.
In antiquity, **Yellow Stone (黄石姿)** taught it to **Jiang Ziya (太公姜子牙)**, and it proved most effective.
Later, **Jiang Ziya** did not pass this method down.
The formula remains in the subsequent annotations.

**Lao Jun** says:
*"Humans are born of the **Five Phases (五行)**,
Beginning their fate with the **Six Jia (六甲)**—
There is flourishing and decline.
When flourishing, the **Southern Dipper (南斗)** governs;
When declining, the **Northern Dipper (北斗)** governs.
The Southern Dipper’s six stars—hence, **Six Jia**.
The Northern Dipper’s seven stars—hence, **Seven Mansions (七宿)**.
The Southern Dipper presides over life; the Northern Dipper, over death—
Thus, life and death belong to the **Two Dippers’ jurisdiction**.
If one commits wicked deeds, the **Northern Dipper’s Celestial Finger (天指)** turns against them.
Human flourishing and decline are all under the **Two Dippers’ scrutiny**.
If evil deeds accumulate to their limit, Heaven must punish—
Then the **Southern Dipper records the name (落名)**,
And the **Northern Dipper executes the form (斩形)**.
All human wickedness is slain by the **Northern Dipper**.
Now, if one commits **Five Evils**—
Rebelling against the **Dao/Way**, betraying the teacher,
Betraying the sovereign, betraying one’s father—
Heaven knows this early.
Yet if there are those with **virtuous intent**,
Serving as sovereign or teacher,
Subduing the wicked and rebellious,
Eradicating evil, upholding the **Rectified Way (正道)**,
And bringing peace to all—
Their merit is vast and enduring.
The Most High rejoices, elevating them to **Celestial Officials (仙官)**,
Sharing governance of the **Ten Heavens (十天)**,
Ascending to the **Supreme Clarity’s True Emperor (上清太真之位)**.
Other rites may save one’s family—
But this rite’s use is for **national salvation**.
Employ talismans and methods as prescribed.

**Lao Jun** instructs **Sìmìng (司命)** and his attendants:
*"In antiquity, **Sìmìng** was an attendant of the **Sovereign Lord (隶君)**—
Not the later **Sìmìng**.
Now, **Han Jun (韩君)** has replaced him—
This is his station.
The **Central Dipper (中斗)**, along with the **Southern and Northern Dippers**,
These three Dippers are upright—
They do not meddle without cause, bringing chaos.
If one petitions for blessings but instead invites calamity,
The **learners of the Dao** must first **know themselves** above all.
In days past, there was a **student of the Dao**, **Guō Shēngzǐ (郭声子)**,
Who burned incense day and night, worshipping the **Northern Dipper** without cease.
For seventeen years, the **Northern Dipper Lord** pursued and reproached him:
*'I, the Northern Dipper, am an **Inspector of Virtue and Vice (纠察之官)**,
Upright in enforcing the Law.
Day and night, I patrol the Nine Heavens.
If any star or constellation commits good or evil,
I know first—
Then I report to the **Celestial Sovereign (上帝)**.
The Sovereign frequently commands **Celestial Messengers and Daoist Officials (天使仙官)**,
To investigate and inspect, lest there be **unjust favoritism**.
We, the **Nine Inspectors (九司)**, always fear punishment for ourselves.
Who are you, so base and ignorant,
Burning incense nightly, publicly announcing to Heaven—
What do you seek?
Your actions have unsettled all nine stars.
Now, your deeds disturb the **Five Phases above**,
And alarm the **Twenty-Eight Constellations below**—
All have gathered to question me:
*"This man is harmless—
Why does he, through licentiousness and chaos,
Draw the **Celestial Inspectors’ scrutiny**?
Why not kill him first, then report?"*
Because you are but a mortal, I spare you—
Not that I harbor malice.
But now, bow and apologize.
Your crimes are threefold:
First, **false invocation**—
Without illness or misfortune, you petition the **Celestial Gate (天关)**,
Demanding the **Gate’s messengers (转关使者)** punish some person or thing.
Second, you **burn incense endlessly**,
Worshipping the Northern Dipper from afar—
I fear the **Chen Star (辰星)** will accuse me,
Claiming I **privately accepted your offerings**.
Third, the **Female Star of the Northern Dipper (北斗女星君)** is of **serene and chaste nature**—
To **wrongfully harm her** would invite retribution upon your lineage.
And the **Northern Dipper’s Imperial Lord (北斗帝尊君)**,
As well as the **Jade Sovereign Star Lord (玉帝君)**—
These two stars are upright and difficult to offend.
Now, I release you—
But never repeat this folly."*
Guō Shēngzǐ was spared and lived again,
But died five days later.
His kin asked why—
He never spoke.
Later, this was recorded in the **Ritual Texts of the Seven Stars and Twenty-Eight Constellations (醮七星及二十八宿文仪)**,
To warn future generations.
If one faces **urgent peril**—
Surrounded by bandits, harassed by officials,
Or stricken with grave illness—
After petitioning, step upon the **Celestial Rope (纲)** and tread the **Earthly Stems (蹑纪)**,
Transform the **Celestial Gate (转天关)**,
And dispel the calamity—
It poses no hindrance and is **swift as water or fire**.
The **Later Sage Sovereign (后圣君)** told **Dàwáng Jūn (大王君)**:
*"The **Central and Northern Dippers**,
If invoked in **genuine distress**, will respond.
But **false petitions** bring ruin.
Refer to the previous annotations.
Those who cultivate the **Supreme Dao (至道)** with sincerity,
First **aid the nation and benefit the people**—this is paramount.
If the realm is not purified, **demonic qi (妖气)** lingers.
If the people are not at peace, the **Dao cannot prevail**.
If one’s practice of the Dao fails,
This is not the heart of a **true Daoist."**

This too is the words of **Lǎojūn (老君)**.

In ancient times, **Fúxià Zǐ (伏夏子)**, the younger brother of **Fúxī (伏牺)**, cultivated the **Dao/Way** and attained immortality. While studying in the mortal realm, he took a small bamboo flute and blew it, imitating the **Fèng (凤)** phoenix’s voice—this is the origin of the **shēng (笙)**.

A **celestial immortal** descended to observe him. Afterward, the immortal informed **Fúxià Zǐ**:
*"You are in danger of military calamity."*

**Fúxià Zǐ** rose and bowed twice, then asked how to avert the military peril. The immortal replied:
*"You may use **Lónghuí (龙回)**, which is the step of the **Earthly Stems (蹑地纪)** method for breaking formations. **Hǔtiào (虎跳)** is the step of the **Fēigāng (飞钢)** today. **Yǐnxīng (引星)** corresponds to the **configuring of ritual garments (配衣)** now. **Zhuǎnshā (转杀)** is done at the fingertips—this is the **Celestial Gate (转天关)** of today. **Cóngjī xiànghuài (从基向坏)** refers to the **foundational alignment (即今之日月建地)** and its **dissolution (即今之日破地)**.

The strategies of martial masters for calculating **isolated and empty formations (孤虚)** resemble these methods, and they are highly reliable. Those of old who were **divine sages (神人)** all employed them. When used correctly, they yield victory.

After **Fúxià Zǐ** learned these methods, he used them to rescue those in **genuine distress (急难)** who practiced the **Dao/Way**. **Lǎojūn (老君)** said:
*"For **Daoist companions (道友)** and **inner kin (内亲)**, surrounded by bandits and facing annihilation—if one can devise a plan to save them, they should employ the **Earthly Stems (金地纪)** method in motion: forward, backward, and reverse, three times. Then configure the ritual garments (**配衣**), turn the **Celestial Gate (转天关)**, and ninefoldly point with the fingers (**指之**). Additionally, grasp the **military talisman (兵符)**, pointing it nine times. Twist the **bandit’s command (贼某命人刀支)**—the **Sword-Support (刀支)** of the **wood-directional bandit (东来木人)** is marked with **metallic-white (金白)**, the **gold-directional bandit (西来金人)** with **flaming-red (火赤)**, the **water-directional bandit (南来水人)** with **earthly-yellow (土黄)**, the **fire-directional bandit (北来火人)** with **water-black (水黑)**, and the **earth-directional bandit (四季上来者土人)** with **bamboo-green (木青)**. The four seasons are represented by **chén, xuǔ, chǒu, wèi (辰戌丑未)**.

When twisting the **Sword-Support (刀支)**, use the hand corresponding to its direction. Then, apply the color as described. Afterward, take out the **military talisman (兵符)** and point it nine times at a distance. The bandits’ resolve will collapse, and they will retreat, lifting the siege without harming your **inner kin (反亲)**. If they refuse to retreat, the **shadow army (阴军)** will strike them, and they will mutually slaughter and destroy each other until none remain.

This method is subtle and of utmost secrecy—do not reveal it to anyone unworthy.

The **Later Sage Sovereign (后圣君)** told the **Celestial Master (天师)**:
*"This talisman is for military use—both to aid the nation in battle and to rescue **Daoist companions (道友)** and one’s own life. There is a talisman, the **Tiger King Talisman (虎王符)**, forged from **gold and copper (金铜)**, measuring either two inches or one and a half inches. The **Celestial Master (本师)** must consecrate and empower it. Then, store it in a **brocade pouch (锦袋)**, ensuring no one ever sees it. Only four may behold it: the **Celestial Master (本师)** and the **protector of the Master (保举师)**. If the protector fails or is struck down remotely, the talisman’s power will vanish, and it will never be seen again. The second category includes **sovereigns receiving subjects (君受臣)** and **subjects receiving sovereigns (臣受君)**. The third are **fathers receiving sons (父受子)** and **sons receiving fathers (子受父)**. The fourth are **husbands and wives (夫妻)**. Others must never see it.

If **Daoist companions (道友)** or **inner kin (内亲)** wish to carry it for healing, seal it tightly and give it to the sick person. The illness will immediately abate. If the sick person secretly examines it, the illness will flare up, and they will die without fail.

**Out-Military Talisman (出军)**
If one personally leads an army and is besieged, and the troops break through the enemy’s formation, the talisman must be tied to the **left elbow (左肘)**. There is another talisman, the **White Tiger Talisman for Breaking Strong Formations (白虎破强阵符)**, also forged from **gold and copper (金铜)**, measuring one and a half inches. Its method of use is the same as the previous talisman’s annotations. All talismans are cast from **gold and copper (金铜)**—the **in-military talisman (入军符)** is tied to the **left elbow (左)**, and the **out-military talisman (出军符)** to the **right elbow (右)**.

Together with the **ritual postures and prohibitions (并式禁制)**, and the **spirit of the talisman (加临相助)**, one will inevitably achieve victory. The enemy will collapse like a mountain—this is highly effective. Do not reveal it to anyone unworthy.

**Lǎojūn (老君)** said:
*"In ancient times, the **Western Hu (西胡)** had a great king who loved the **Dao/Way**. I instructed him through the **Hu Immortal (胡仙)**, and he changed his name to **Fó (佛)**—a different name for **celestial immortal (仙)**. The Hu called him **Fó**.

The Four **Celestial Realms (天国)** did not submit, each fielding **strong armies (强兵)** of four hundred thousand men. They surrounded this king’s realm, layer upon layer. The king begged for deliverance but refused to comply. His **true heart (正心)** and **sincere intent (思存)** were evident—I saw him in the void, calling for my aid.

I used the **Earthly Stems (蹑地纪)** to scatter radiance, the **Yǔbù (禹步)** to turn the **Celestial Gate (关)**, and pointed three times. Then, I released a **military talisman (出军一符)** toward the Hu king’s desk. The king saw it, tied it to his **left elbow (左手肘)**, and later opened the city gates to battle. Those who fought against this king all fell backward, and the enemy armies were utterly defeated, slaughtered by the city’s defenders.

In but a moment, the **heavens and earth (天地)** grew enraged, and thunderous winds shook the heavens and earth. White rain descended, annihilating the Four **Celestial Armies (天军)**. The armies and their king scattered and fled back to their own lands, unharmed in their positions.

Thus, the **virtue/power (力)** of this talisman is supreme. Guard it carefully—do not let anyone unworthy see it. If they do, both parties will face retribution, and the **Heaven’s great wrath (天大威)** will bring death. This is no trivial matter—be cautious, be cautious.

**The Method of the Red Chapter for Aiding the Nation and Subduing Bandits (赤章助国伐贼法)**
**Tàishàng Lǎojūn (太上老君)** said:
*"Rescue is the **virtue/power (功)** of aiding the nation in subduing bandits, saving the nation from difficulty. When **kings and emperors (国王帝主)** dispatch great ministers to attack rebellious bandits, but are instead besieged—if one is a **master of martial law (掌法)** and a **true Daoist (志道之人)**, they should aid the nation in its salvation.

Use the **Red Chapter (上赤章)** to summon the **Heavenly Armies (天兵)**, turn the **Celestial Gate (转天关)** to rescue them—swift as water or fire in urgency. If the nation’s strong bandits retreat, with neither side harmed, this is the highest outcome.

If the bandits are **strong and unyielding (强梁不伏)**, petition the **Heavenly Sovereign (天公)**—now called **Yùhuáng Dìshàng (玉皇上帝)**—and write their crimes. This is **Heaven’s retribution (天施功)**. If the **virtue/power (功)** is great and **Heaven does not strike (天不伐)**, the act of **subduing and killing (蹑杀)** will instead be recorded as the **hidden merit (阴功)** of saving people.

**Nurturing and protecting all beings (安养人物)**.
This pleases **Heaven greatly (此天大喜)**, and **Heaven will devise a plan (与计)** for the **hidden merit (阴功)**.

Later sages changed this to the **Red Chapter (赤章)**—a **chapter of petition against traitors (章奏反臣章)**—saying, *'Tàixuān Dū (泰玄都)' and so forth."*

The Sovereign humbly follows the written petition: *"In such-and-such state and county, a certain person [X] has rebelled for such-and-such reason.*

Now the state commands a certain minister [Y] to lead an army of tens of thousands of soldiers and horses to the border of such-and-such state, to attack the rebel forces numbering tens of thousands. Fearful that their troops are fierce, rebellious, and strong, recklessly slaughtering the innocent and resisting the righteous, refusing to submit, the minister now finds himself besieged within such-and-such city’s encampment, unable to escape, with his life hanging by a thread. He seeks the minister’s salvation.

The minister petitions for **Heavenly troops**: humbly requesting the descent of the **Nine Heavenly Great Mighty Gods**, the **Nine Great Generals**, with **ninety million soldiers**, to unite with the minister’s **talismanic army of ninety million**, summoning the **nine million earthly community temple troops** to secretly deploy and array themselves. When the minister’s [X] **sun-facing troops** sound the battle drum, the troops shall immediately strike in response, aiding in the assault against the rebels. Their fierce and treacherous forces shall collapse in an instant—like mountains crumbling to dust, or stones shattering—sand collapsing, deer fleeing, surrendering and clearing the path for the general’s forces to emerge victorious.

All manner of beasts and birds—**Phoenix** (凤凰), **Peng** (鹏), **Golden-Winged** (金翅)—
each one restrained and captured, then cast down to the earthly realm for judgment.
They are released to ascend once more.
Together with the winds, clouds, rains, snows, frosts, and dews,
they obey the **Daoist** (道) will and respond to invocation,
and their cessation is immediate and potent.*

For the **spirited beasts and birds** (灵禽兽) that dwell above, they uphold the **Heavenly Dao-qi** (天正气), the **Dao’s** (道) own manifestation. These beasts also assist the **Dao-qi** (正气) and perpetually guard and protect those who embody the **Dao** (有道之人). They must not be recklessly restrained or forbidden.

If restrained, they lose their vigor and strength—
their ability to soar through the clouds and traverse the skies diminishes daily.
When beasts and birds are forbidden from their natural heroic prowess and courage,
they cannot maintain their strength, their soaring through the clouds weakens daily,
and they perish in exhaustion.

**Mischievous beasts and birds** (妖兽妖禽), however, must be restrained.
If not restrained, they descend to the lower realms and wreak havoc (作妖变),
plaguing humanity (祟害人物), causing unrest among all.
Thus, it is appropriate to restrain them.
But if they are not acting maliciously (不为妖祟),
they must not be arbitrarily forbidden—
forbidding them is to defy **Heaven** (反天).
Beware of this.

The **Later Sage Emperor** (后圣君) declared:
*'Among the **Dragons** (龙), there are **Mischievous Dragons** (妖龙);
among the **Tigers** (虎), there are **Mischievous Tigers** (妖虎);
all celestial beasts (天兽) may manifest as **monstrous** (妖怪).
They must be restrained as needed, lest they harm humanity.
The method of restraint: first, tread the **Earthly Memorial** (地纪) three times,
then fly the **Celestial Halter** (飞天纲) three times,
and recite the incantations.
The **Earthly Memorial** has eighteen incantations,
the **Celestial Halter** has twelve.
When the incantations are complete,
perform the **Yubu Steps** (禹步), don the ritual garments (配衣),
turn the **Heavenly Barrier** (天关) nine times,
and point downward nine times (指之九下).
Then issue the **summons** (牒) to follow the beasts,
commanding those of similar kind to capture them,
and bring them to the **Daoist assembly** (道场) for judgment.
When the incantations are complete,
dissolve into the **Yubu Steps** (禹步), don the ritual garments (配衣),
turn the **Celestial Halter** (天关) nine times,
and point downward nine times (指之九度).
Dispatch agents (使者) of corresponding rank,
seize the summons (把牒),
and pursue their capture.
Once they arrive, interrogate and sentence them,
then release them—
do not kill them recklessly.
To halt the **violent wind** (狂风):
The **Laozi** said: First tread the **Earthly Memorial** (地纪) three times,
then fly the **Celestial Halter** (天纲) three times,
and recite the incantations.
The incantations must not be spoken aloud (不得高),
lest human ears hear them—
for if heard, the **Heavenly Dragons** (天龙) and **Dao-spirits** (神) will not submit.*

The **Laozi** commands the **Seven Stars of the Big Dipper** (北斗七星):
*"Within the **Heavenly Dao** (大道),
the **Dao** is upright and balanced.
The **Dao-spirits** (神) are just and without malice,
the **Dragons** (龙) are upright and without excess,
and **ghosts and mischievous beings** (鬼妖) dare not move.
The unjust dare not act.
Why then does this **violent wind** (狂风) arise,
disturbing the **Heavenly Court** (天庭),
snapping trees and toppling houses?
The **Laozi** captures you—
the **Warrant** (符) and **Summons** (牒) are now invoked.
You **malicious Dao-spirits** (凶神) and **mischievous Dragons** (妖龙),
shall no longer generate wind.
As swift as the **Dao’s decree** (律令).*
When the incantations are complete,
dissolve into the **Yubu Steps** (禹步):
first three steps with nine traces (前三步九迹),
then transform into twelve traces (次即变为十二迹),
then transform into fifteen traces (次即变十五迹).
Then don the ritual garments (配衣),
turn the **Celestial Halter** (天关) nine times,
and point downward (转指之).
In secret, issue the **summons** (牒) to dispatch the **Day-Symbol Soldiers** (日神) and **Form-Symbol Soldiers** (式神) with their **Divine Cavalry** (兵马),
led by the **City Deities and Community Altars** (社稷神) and their forces,
to capture the **Wind-Generating Dao-spirits** (行风神), the **Dragons** (龙), and **ghosts** (鬼).
Sentence them according to their crimes (科央).
At the moment of invocation, the wind shall cease utterly,
swift as water and fire parting.
Twist the **mnemonic formula** (捻诀)—
the formula lies on the second joint of the left hand’s second finger,
the third joint of the second finger,
and the second joint of the third finger.
Twisting it shall halt the wind.

**Golden Lock, Flowing Pearl Scroll** (金锁流珠引) **Volume Twenty-Four**

The **Grand Sovereign of the Dao’s True Perfection**, **Zaiwang Fangping**, **Zhang Daoling**, **Zhao Sheng**, **Wang Chang**, **Siziming Li Zhongfu**, **Mao Ying**, **Xu Yufu**, and others—these are the successive compilers and annotators of the **Chinese Daoists**. **Master Li Chunfeng** annotated the **Method of Summoning Dragons and Restraining Serpents**.

This is what **Lord Fan** and **Lord Liu** held in highest regard: in the human realm, there are venomous tigers and leopards; in the celestial realm, there are venomous dragons. This method is used to restrain them.

**Laozi said:** *"To summon dragons, one must do so at night in a pure chamber, free of women. Only then will it succeed. If a woman is nearby, it will not respond to the call."*

Within the chamber, do not enter a woman’s quarters, nor should a woman enter a man’s. After three days, one may tread the **Earthly Restraint** (*jì*) and the **Celestial Leash** (*gāng*), each three times.

Disseminate the **Yubu Steps** in nine strides, then **twist the eyes**—the **Dragon-Tiger Eyes**. With the left hand, grasp the talisman and summon nine times downward; it will arrive instantly.

Some say: *"Further, align the garments, turn the Heavenly Pass nine times, and it will surely come."*

Dragons and tigers are thus fully summoned, each with their respective talismans as prescribed.

In the past, during the **Later Han’s destruction of Wei**, **Fan and Liu** excelled in this summoning method.

According to *The Authentic Biography of Lady Fan*, Lady Fan was the twelfth-generation granddaughter of **Fan Kuai**, a high-ranking officer of **Emperor Gaozu of Han**. Her maternal grandfather was **Wang Zheng**, the seventeenth-generation descendant of **Wang Qiao**. Across generations, they inherited the **qi-sealing techniques**.

From childhood, Lady Fan lost her mother and was raised by her maternal grandfather, Zheng. As a child, she loved reading, and her grandfather taught her. At thirteen, she abandoned formal studies and devoted herself to reading the *Liujia* (Six Canons), the *Rites*, and the *Yijing*. Suddenly, in the secret archives of her maternal ancestor’s thirteenth-generation home, she discovered **Laozi’s *Liujia Talismans*** (seven volumes), the ***Seven Stars Step and Leash Rites*** (ten volumes), and this ***Summoning Scripture*** (over twenty volumes). She would steal away daily to read them in the woods near her home—sometimes a hundred paces, sometimes fifty—repeatedly.

After three years, while in the woods, she suddenly saw a young woman.

The woman asked: *"Do you love the Dao?"*
She replied: *"Though my years are young, I love the Dao greatly. I have studied this book, which teaches the art of eternal life and immortality. Later, I shall attain the Way of the Immortal. This world rarely hears such teachings. Common folk know nothing of this Dao-scripture, and the world would otherwise have none. Thus, in my youth, I cherished its words, reading them three or five times before committing them to memory."*

The female immortal said: *"I am the Immortal Alwang Xiao. I teach you to read this book. From now on, whenever you have leisure, come here. I will guide you further and teach you the methods of its practice."*

Thus, from that day forward, whenever she had free time, she would secretly go alone at noon. After two years, her maternal grandmother noticed her absence and secretly followed her to the forest, where she saw her reading with a woman. Delighted, she said nothing to others, but listened in silence for three years, until her Daoic studies were complete.

When her mastery was achieved, she could command ghosts and spirits like servants, bending them to her will as easily as turning her hand. She could communicate with spirits, summon and bind tigers and leopards—nothing was beyond her power.

During the reign of Emperor Wen of Wei, there was a great drought lasting over seventy days, with the sun blazing red and no clouds in sight. The emperor sought rain through every means but found no answer. The county officials recommended Lady Fan’s granddaughter, who had mastered Daoic arts, could summon tigers and leopards, and command ghosts and spirits to petition for rain.

The emperor ordered his concubine, Lady Zhao Dan, to write a request on silk, commanding her to seek rain. At the time, Lady Fan was indoors, ashamed and reluctant to comply. Lady Zhao reasoned with her: *"You are of the Wang clan by birth. Why conceal your lineage? Given the current drought, saving lives brings merit. If the people are at peace, how can you withhold such virtue?"*

Lady Fan then composed a letter to the Dragon King, which was sent into a deep pool. Rain fell immediately.

At fifteen, she married into the Liu family and traveled with her husband as an official across the empire. Later, her husband, Liu Gang, learned of her abilities and, with proper rites, requested her teachings. He received ten volumes of the scripture and was given diagrams of the Three Elements and Six Canons, along with the Seven Stars.

Over fifty years later, the couple both ascended as immortals. In the Eastern Mountains of Kuaiji, his wife sat upon a cloud-driven dragon chariot and departed. Her husband ascended a *zhaojia* tree and followed her. The Daoist records then conferred upon her the title of *Xian Guan*, a mid-ranking true immortal.

**The Supreme Lord Laozi’s Golden-Mouthed Edict: *The Female Qing-Shao Scripture for Protecting Households and Families (Zheng Ritual)***
*"Heaven is my resolute heart. My disciples and those who follow my teachings must act with sincerity and justice, rescuing beings from sickness and calamity."*

**Calamities** are of ten kinds:
1. Heavenly epidemic plagues—those who practice this teaching with sincerity shall not be blamed by Heaven.
2. Seasonal prohibitions—no harm shall come from them.
3. Official misdeeds—none shall be unjust.
4. Fire, 5. Water, 6. War.
7. Ghostly possession and malevolent spirits, 8. Poverty and hardship, 9. Deafness and blindness, 10. Internal ghosts.

For my summoned disciples, each year on the first day of the first month, before dawn when people are still asleep, they must issue talismans to protect their households, ensuring safety and freedom from disease and plague.

The **Supreme Lord Laozi’s Golden-Mouthed Edict** states:
*"The six Canons of the sixty days must be inscribed, listing the names of malevolent ghosts, along with the Female Qing Ritual, all contained within the Ghostly Statutes. Three copies must be placed at the head of the talisman: one at the community shrine, one at the ancestral hall, and one above the household door. After one year, the household shall forever be free from calamity, plague, and illness, and disputes shall naturally dissolve.*

*"Additionally, one must recite the *Diezhi Ji* and the *Feitian Gang* three times each, stepping in the Nine-Step Yujubu formation. The incantation is as follows:*

*'Sue poison, sue poison,
Sue disease, sue evil,
Sue ghosts, sue serpents,
Sue speech, sue tongue,
Sue rats, sue mice,
Sue waste, sue water,
Sue metal, sue fire,
Sue earth, sue wood,
Sue deceit, O Lord of Men!*

*One hundred twenty sues—sue swiftly, sue and disperse!*
*Swiftly, as the decree commands!*

*When reciting this incantation loudly, hold the written talisman in the left hand and pinch the *Dujian* talisman in the right, uttering each ‘sue’ while making a downward gesture with the hand—this brings great fortune."*

The Highest True Immortals perform this ritual annually without fail.

Laozi said: *"The path of Dao has gates, and the pursuit of Truth has roads. To obtain the gate is to attain *tong*—communion with spirits. When one studies the Dao and attains the gate, they possess *wei*—power to command ghosts, spirits, and the heavens, making them respond. This is called *shentong*—spiritual penetration. To obtain the road is to become an immortal. Immortals are the rank of True Persons. Those who practice the True Person’s Way and master this thirty-plus volume scripture, penetrating the Golden Talismans, later become known as the *Golden Lock Flowing Pearl Scripture*, harmonizing the Three Elements, emerging from the Upper Clarity, encompassing the Orthodox Unity—this is the path and the road to communion, enabling one to ride dragons and traverse the void, named the *Path of Daoic Cultivation to Communion*. Later, one may ride dragons and walk upon the clouds, wandering freely in the Purple Palace, near the rank of the Immortal Officials.*

*If practiced for nine years, a household shall have no sickness. If practiced for twenty years, the entire family shall attain Daoic power. This method is akin to the *Bazhe* (House-Transference) technique.*

**Note:** This ritual must be performed in the last days of the twelfth month (the 26th or 27th), inscribing the talismans and edicts of the Ghostly Statutes, with the master’s seal. At the stroke of three in the morning on the first day of the first month, the incantation must be recited. Modern practitioners no longer recite the words on the talisman—only the incantation is heard.

**A Comprehensive Ritual for Protecting Officials’ Households and Families from Calamity**
This is also included in the *New Chapter Rites*.

Laozi said to Master Xu: *"Xu Le, you are a master who protects and delivers from calamity. Now you are Zhang Ti, known as the Three Heavenly Orthodoxy Master. Now you are also Xiao Zhang, succeeding Da Zhang as the Celestial Master. You teach disciples to become national masters, to protect the inner palaces of the state and to pacify the distant prefectures and counties of the people.

First, present the Six Divine Writings of Heaven. Later, the Sage changed the titles and texts, making them into the Chapter Writings. The Most High approved them, granting talismans and edicts to the Five Sacred Mountains and Four Great Waters, to the cities and ancestral shrines. There are thirty-six volumes of grand proclamations and talismans. The remaining seven volumes: six are to be placed in sacred mountain caves, and one in the Water Palace. All these are rituals to be recited in a low, quiet voice, without musical resonance.

These are all Yang methods, human ordinances. The term *academy* (社) was once called *assembly* (斋), now changed to *gathering* (齐会). *Gathering* means to discuss and study scriptures. When performing the talisman rituals, first step on the *Earth Measure*, then ascend the *Heavenly Rope*, each three times. When summoning a master or disciple-master, and summoning scribes and officials: If traveling with family or oneself to another prefecture, first issue an edict to the ancestral temples and city gods. Laozi commands the spirits of the shrines: When summoning, the master’s name must be written. For travelers with family, issue an edict five days in advance to the Nine Regions’ community leaders—Wu Zixu is one. If not summoning a proper master, issue an edict with the name written above and the scribe’s name below. If summoning a master from the Nine Regions, use a proper edict without talismans—talismans are on the edict’s head, not the seal.
