chunks.original_text: 与某处 州县乡里。 姓名，与某相加谋，欲以相敌，敌却相 谋杀。 臣今行阴纲，与隔解之。 咒曰： 令被此不嗔，各欢相代，阻膈山海俱难。 吾转天关，各指指后。 欲前举心者，心身自寒，各须伏心获安。 犯吾此令者，魂魄守天盘。 盘训伐罪也。 右斗上十二步，盘上三十四步。 旧说云：顺、倒一反於纲上，便为之。 今之是顺、倒、反三遍。 今按后圣君授方诸小童君及王君口诀云：顺、倒两遍，毕，向阳星纲头起，右散行三遍。 讫，上纲左足蹑阳明星。 次右足蹑阴精。 又先前右足蹑玄冥，左足蹑丹元。 次右足蹑北极，左足蹑天关，右足次前，与左足并，乃通气祝曰： 金木相克，木日相伐。 水火相灭，铜口铁舌。 前举者折，二心各退。 两舌无说，二心俱伏。 不相诛灭，吾出阴兵，制汝二人，心怨休歇。 急急如律令。 祝讫，各捻左右刀支少间。 注：刀支，上卷具注讫。 此更云：在左手第五指第三节右边是诀。 此法为人修行，令怨对不相加伐，并被人谋害，自身为之。 或彼人有心，此人不对，常恐来责伐我身，求请阻隔，令永不来者。 以与三夜为之，不令人见之。 见之即不神验也。 注：夫人行阴功阴德，其阴功阴德未成，便被阳人知见，见便即一口发言，千口动舌，却为阴过。 更敢望修行其阴功助人，而复被阴官所责也。 若自行阴功，助国护身救人者，前从地纪三遍。 讫 顺倒反三遍是也。
chunks.translated_text:
「Now, I invoke the **Heavenly Rites Diagram** upon the **State County Village** of the aforementioned **official** (or **common folk**),
   and the **person** whose name is [given]—together they conspire, seeking to harm each other,
   yet their plots are thwarted and they turn to **conspire and murder** one another.
   I now perform the **Yin Rites** to **sever their enmity**.
   The incantation reads: *"Let those under this curse feel no resentment,
   and may they each rejoice in taking turns to suffer.
   Let mountains and seas obstruct their paths with difficulty.
   I now turn the **Heavenly Rites Diagram**—each shall bear their due retribution.
   Those who harbor forward intentions, may their **heart and body grow cold**,
   and each must **suppress their heart** to find peace.
   Violators of this decree shall have their **soul and vital essence bound to the Heavenly Punishment Diagram**.
   The **Heavenly Punishment Diagram** is a **ritual of retribution and guilt**.
   *(The following steps are performed:)* Twelve steps to the **Right Star**,
   thirty-four steps to the **Heavenly Punishment Diagram**.
   The ancient method says: *"Two cycles—forward and backward—upon the Heavenly Rites Diagram,
   and the deed is done."*
   But now, we perform **three cycles**—forward, backward, and reversed.
   According to the **posterity’s incantation** given by the **Saintly Sovereign** to the young disciples **Xiao-tong Jun** and **Wang Jun**:
   *"Two cycles—forward and backward—are complete.
   Then, beginning from the **Sun Yang Star** at the head of the **Heavenly Rites Diagram**,
   scatter three cycles to the right."*
   When finished, **step with the left foot upon the Sun Yang Star**,
   then **step with the right foot upon the Yin Jing Star**.
   Again, first **step with the right foot upon the Xuan Ming Star**,
   then **step with the left foot upon the Dan Yuan Star**.
   Next, **step with the right foot upon the North Pole**,
   then **step with the left foot upon the Heavenly Rites Diagram**,
   and **step the right foot forward**, aligning with the left foot.
   Now, **unify and bless the qi**, saying:

   *"Metal overcomes Wood, Wood is felled by Fire.
   Water extinguishes Fire, and the **mouth of bronze** and **tongue of iron** are silenced.
   The forward-thinking one is broken, the two hearts retreat.
   The two tongues speak no more, both hearts are subdued.
   They shall not slaughter each other—
   I now summon the **Yin Forces** to constrain you two,
   and let your **grudges and enmity** cease.
   As it is decreed by the **Heavenly Mandate**."*

   When the blessing concludes, **twirl the fingers of the left and right hand’s fifth digit** for a short while.

   *Note:* The **finger joints** are fully annotated in the previous section.

   This further states: *"On the **right side of the third joint of the left hand’s fifth finger** is the **key incantation**."*
   This method is for **practitioners** to cultivate,
   so that those harboring **grudges and enmity** do not harm each other,
   nor conspire against one another’s life—
   the **self** shall act upon this.
   Or, if one fears that the other may act upon them,
   and they dread future **retribution and blame** upon their own body,
   they may **pray for obstruction and separation**, so that the other never comes again.
   *(This is done)* over **three nights**, without letting others see it.
   If seen, the **spiritual efficacy** will not manifest.

   *Note:* When a person cultivates **Yin Merits** and **Yin Virtue**,
   if their **Yin Merits** and **Yin Virtue** are not yet fulfilled,
   they will be exposed by a **Yang Person**—once seen,
   a thousand tongues will stir, and it becomes a **Yin Fault**.
   How much more so if they dare to **cultivate Yin Merits to aid others**,
   only to be **accused by Yin Officials**?
   If one **cultivates Yin Merits** for **protecting the state, safeguarding life, and rescuing others**,
   they should first perform **three cycles upon the Earthly Measures Diagram**.
   When finished, **three cycles—forward, backward, and reversed—are complete.*"

chunks.original_text: 即飞天纲三遍，讫即散变三步九迹禹步，击止之。 如恐不止，即十二步禹步一遍，又步十五步。 存上中下三将军，领兵各三千万众，及六甲诸神，一一存如含弘图，及《流珠》中元下元等三将军图。 击之三度，万事自消，亦不苦损彼人。 若六度为之，彼人病，不可妄行，损己阴功。 九度为之，彼立殒。 注：不可妄行之，损己阴功，以成阴过也。 禹步三等，并以图在上引中。 讫今此禹步，以存作山隔断相敌之人，阵法诀步图。 右转一转，存为九重山，隔此人魂神，畏而不来也。 此名地轴禹步，存二十四地轴神，开一寸之地，而为万里江山，或万里江山，摄为一寸步之地。 此禹步微妙，能伏摄於人身，腾空而不知远近也。 诀在左手第一指根三横文中，是地心诀也。 注：亦得师示文理之极，露处得真诀。 步纲三遍，讫即以右手捻左手中诀，讫又踏地，举足下地心诀，及地里诀。 即咒曰： 天清地平，日月顺行，人物俱泰，国得君贞。 今有某人逆天喧呼，臣履禹纲，隔断常为。 千山万坑不得过，过者全军身不生。 以取本色石，掷之便止。 本色石，在六甲箓中看取，即得也。 此步纲非但作阴功救人，而常行之，三年立可缩地脉，往往甚速於飞空。 注：昔壶公先生姓施，名存。 孔夫子弟子也。

Summon the **Three Marshals of Upper, Middle, and Lower** realms, each commanding **three hundred million troops**, along with the **Six Jia deities**, invoking them as in the *Hunpeng Diagram* and the *Liuzhu* [scroll]’s **Three Marshals of Yuanxia and Yuanxia-inferior** diagrams. Strike three times—all matters will dissolve, and no harm will befall that person. If done **six times**, the person will fall ill; do not act recklessly, lest your **Yin Virtue** be diminished. If done **nine times**, they will perish instantly.
*Note:* Do not act recklessly—this diminishes your **Yin Virtue**, turning it into a **Yin Fault**.

The **three grades of the Yu Step** are illustrated above in the diagrams referenced earlier. Now, with this Yu Step, you may **invoke the Mountain Barrier** to sever the enemy, following the **Array Formation Step Diagram**. Turning right once, summon the **Ninefold Mountains** to isolate their spirit and soul, so they dare not approach.

This is called the **Earthly Axis Yu Step**, invoking the **Twenty-Four Earthly Axis Deities**, opening a **one-cun** space to encompass **ten thousand li of rivers and mountains**, or **ten thousand li of rivers and mountains** condensed into a **one-cun step**. This Yu Step is subtle and profound—it can **subdue and gather** within a person’s body, allowing them to soar through the void without knowing distance.

The secret lies within the **three horizontal marks** at the base of the **left hand’s first finger**; this is the **Earth-Core Secret**. *Note:* One may also receive the teacher’s revelation of its ultimate principle, uncovering the true secret where it is exposed.

After completing the **three cycles of the Step Ropes**, pinch the **left hand’s central secret** with the right, then stamp the ground, lifting the foot to invoke the **Earth-Core Secret** and the **Earth-Inner Secret**. Then recite the incantation:

chunks.original_text: 以师孔之业，求仕数不达。 乃仰天而叹曰：我心犹欲，求至道至尊，玉皇上帝殿下之臣，万重云台玉京左殿卿相。 何况於世人皇帝下，求一小臣，如许难得，即弃儒书，学道尊师。 初遇西州赵公，遂法师学读经籍，声启朝修礼念之道，精志不休，三十七年，渐觉沈昏，困老无力。 又仰天而叹曰：何幸天生我愚身，学儒儒道成而不荣，学道心志　苦而不明，岂非我身无宿因福，运命不行，奈何任老而死。 须突之间，闷绝而死。 死中忽见一女人，甚美貌绝世。 告存曰：汝学道不逢明师，不知修行求智慧之心，坚金刚之身，劳遵花五色之藏，唯学歌音之声，诵读闲语，作小儿之学，学咔音句之能，去道渐遥。 若为得道，汝可改行别学，须往少室山中，寻九灵先生，九灵先生是老君分身也。 一云是老君弟子王夫人。 人生善修行阴功阴德，今道已成，须以早去，勿在迟迟。 於是施存得觉，便往少室山中，寻求三月日不遇。 但以清净，齐心不移。 忽於路傍逢一老人，年可七八十许，皓首，行步如虎，力状可负别人。 施存视之良久，知是神人，即走趋下情而拜。 路人惊怪，问曰：拜此老人何也。 众中有一人曰：真人相见，趋谒之礼也。 於是九灵先生责曰：汝来何迟，吾欲将汝入王屋山，谒六甲夫人，久待汝来，天曹有符，下令授汝，修行六甲阴功，服符治身，身今已老，何不早修。 於是施存伏地，叩头再拜，唯称死而再生，得遇见先生。 伏愿先生教以不死之法，得延贱下之躯不死。 伏为奴仆之使，使不论年月，唯愿妆录，以乞余生。 九灵先生便将入王屋山，三年，教行蹑步天纲地纪之法，吞饵六甲灵飞之文，及授地轴之符箓二十四阶，常转地轴天关，阴而修满十四年，道成。 已将一壶，可容二升之器，以包罗大罗天之下、太极之中世界，以入壶中。 或壶为六甲营，出炁禁之术为箓，授度世人，以行阴功阴德。 岂非心之至，而感神人为师，教授成道。 后更游世七百年，至晋时为费长房所遇，教长房缩地脉之法，三日宿壶中受法。 归早三周年，一旦太平金阙后圣玉皇上道君，使仙人玉女下迎，上升为左仙上卿之位，如世太常卿相似。 果其太上大道，不违施存之愿见赐仙卿。 第三条阴功，学道法成，阴功可济。 若道功着，常观世间，有凶神毒龙妖鬼，妄行狂风暴雨，伤损人物，不论水陆，步蹑天纲地纪各三遍， 具前说步天地纲图 散为禹步九迹，十二迹，或十五迹，常转配天关，举手指之三六九， 注：或三度，毒祆自止，可不损其命。 六度指病，九指频死，不可妄行禁杀，非道也。 须以察知实，以害人妄作祆怪三度两度，人物众皆是安，乃可动法步纲。 度其妖自止。 止而即放，不可便杀。 杀之即捻其龙神鬼之妖精兽等刀支，其妖兽等即三日内自死。 后圣君告《金锁流珠》掌诀，众物龙兽等用诀刀支，皆在此中。 用此看验得。 君曰：不可妄行，行者皆伤他命，有罪於众人物。 人物不安，伤人物命，或作水旱，败伤众命，以法收斩。 注：天关所止，指是九指，是斩也。 以一命而救得十命，谓之倍功。 救数满三千，白日升天。 注：风按《晋书》、《神灵异记》曰：许逊身为旌阳县宰，而学神仙禹步之道。
chunks.translated_text:
With the Master Kong’s teachings,
he sought office repeatedly yet failed.
Then, gazing heavenward, he sighed:
*"My heart still yearns—
to seek the Supreme Dao, the Most Exalted,
as a minister beneath the Jade Emperor’s throne,
in the lofty halls of the Ten Thousand Clouds, the Left Palace of the Celestial Capital.
How much harder, then, to seek even a lowly official
beneath the worldly emperor’s rule—
such a thing is so rare!
Thus, I abandoned Confucian texts
and turned to the Dao, seeking a worthy teacher.*

*First, I met Master Zhao of the Western Prefecture,
and followed him as teacher, studying scriptures.
My voice chanted the rites of morning reverence—
my resolve never wavered.
For thirty-seven years,
I grew ever more enveloped in murky ignorance,
weakened by age, powerless to act.
Again, I sighed to Heaven:
‘How fortunate that Heaven granted me this foolish body—
I studied Confucianism, mastered its ways, yet gained no honor.
I sought the Dao, my heart labored in vain, my wisdom never brightened.
Was it not because my past virtues were meager,
my fate unkind?
How could I now grow old and die?’

In a sudden flash, I fainted and died.
Yet in death, I saw a woman of surpassing beauty,
who spoke to me, saying:
‘You sought the Dao but lacked a true master.
You did not cultivate wisdom with iron resolve,
nor temper your body like adamantine.
You toiled only over the Five-Colored Flower’s hidden teachings,
singing idle tunes, reciting frivolous words,
like a child playing with hollow syllables.
Your path grows ever more distant from the Dao.
If you truly wish to attain it,
abandon these ways and seek another path.
Go to Mount Shaoshi,
and find Master Jiuling—
Jiuling is the Lord Lao’s emanation.
Or some say he is Master Wang’s disciple, the Lady of the Six Jia.’

‘A mortal who cultivates meritorious deeds in secret
may now find the Dao complete—
yet you must depart swiftly, not linger.’

Thus, Shi Cun awoke
and journeyed to Mount Shaoshi,
searching for three months without success.
Yet with a pure heart, unwavering resolve,
he suddenly encountered an old man on the road—
seventy or eighty years old, with snow-white hair,
walking like a tiger, strong enough to bear another man.
Shi Cun gazed long, recognizing him as a divine being,
and hurried forward to bow in reverence.
The bystanders were astonished and asked:
‘Why do you bow to this old man?’
One among them replied:
‘When encountering a True Person, one must pay homage with haste.’

Then Jiuling Master scolded:
‘Why have you come so late?
I wished to take you to Mount Wangwu,
to pay respects to the Lady of the Six Jia.
I have waited long—
Heaven’s records have decreed
that I should instruct you in cultivating the Six Jia’s meritorious deeds,
and prescribe the talismans to heal your body.
Yet you are already old—
why did you not begin sooner?’

Shi Cun fell to the ground, kowtowing twice,
declaring he had been reborn only to meet this master.
He begged:
‘I humbly pray that the master teach me the art of immortality,
so that my wretched body may endure.
I would serve as your slave,
regardless of years or months—
only grant me this life.’

Jiuling Master then led him into Mount Wangwu,
and for three years,
taught him the method of *stepping the Celestial Halter and Earthly Measures*,
to swallow the *Six Jia’s Soul-Soaring Scriptures*,
and bestowed the *Twenty-Four Stages of the Earth’s Axis Talismans*,
always turning the Earth’s Axis and Heaven’s Gate.
After fourteen years of secret cultivation,
his Dao was complete.

He then took a jar—
a vessel of two *sheng* capacity—
which could contain the entire world beneath the Great Luo Heaven,
within the Great Polarity’s embrace,
and sealed it inside.
Or the jar was the Six Jia’s encampment,
and the *Scriptures of Qi-Sealing Arts* were its talismans,
to transmit to mortals for cultivating meritorious deeds in secret.

Was it not because his heart was most sincere
that the divine master took him as a disciple,
and guided him to attainment?

Later, he wandered the world for seven hundred years,
until the Jin Dynasty, when Fei Changfang encountered him
and learned the method of *shortening the Earth’s pulse*.
For three days, he hosted Fei in his jar to receive the teachings.
Upon returning, three years passed,
when one day, the Most Holy Jade Emperor of the Golden Threshold
sent celestial maidens to welcome him,
and he ascended to the rank of *Left Celestial Marshal*,
akin to the worldly Grand Councilor.

Truly, the Supreme Dao was fulfilled—
his wish to be granted the Celestial Marshal’s rank was answered.

**The Third Rule of Yin Merits:**
When the Dao’s power is manifest,
one observes the world—
if malevolent spirits, poisonous dragons, or demons
unleash raging winds and torrential rains,
harming all beings, whether on land or sea,
one must tread the *Celestial Halter and Earthly Measures*
three times each, as described in the *Diagram of Stepping Heaven and Earth’s Measures*.
Dissolve into the *Yugbu Steps*—
nine strides, twelve strides, or fifteen strides—
and always align with the Heaven’s Gate.
Raise the hand and point with three, six, or nine fingers.
*Note: Some say three times—
the poisonous spirits will then cease,
and no lives will be harmed.*

Six strikes for illness,
nine for imminent death—
do not recklessly invoke these prohibitions to kill,
for that is not the Dao.

One must first discern the truth—
if harm is being wrought by malevolent spirits,
and they act with demonic fury three or two times,
then all beings will be at peace,
and only then may the *Step-Halter Method* be applied.
The demons will then cease.

Cease and release them—
do not kill outright.
If you kill, pluck the *dragon-spirit’s vital thread* from their demonic beasts—
the beasts will die within three days.

Later, the Sage Monarch revealed the *Golden Lock, Flowing Pearl* manual,
where all methods for subduing dragons and beasts are recorded.
Use this to verify.

The Sage said:
‘Do not act recklessly—
those who do will harm others’ lives,
and bear guilt before all beings.
If beings are unsettled,
or lives are lost to drought or flood,
the lawful method must be applied to execute judgment.
*Note: The “Heaven’s Gate” cessation refers to the nine strikes—
this is the execution.*

To save one life and gain ten is called *double merit*.
When three thousand are saved,
one ascends to Heaven in broad daylight.
*Note: Regarding the wind, as recorded in the *Book of Jin* and *Strange Records of the Divine*,
Xu Xun served as the magistrate of Jingyang County,
yet mastered the Dao of the *Yugbu Steps*.’

chunks.translated_text:
The Great Serpent of Shu, with three coils,
and the Six Poisonous Dragons of the Han River,
together plagued the people as *spirits of calamity*,
blocking the river and ridges fore and aft,
seizing humans to devour.
When Heaven learned of this,
Xu Xun’s *Dao/Way* was perfected in the *Yugbu Steps*,
and he treaded the *Yugbu Steps’* path,
turning the *Heaven’s Gate* strike—
he captured and slew them.
He did not exceed the *nine strikes’* limit on *spirits of calamity*,
yet saved over ten thousand lives.

This serpent appeared in a dream to the Jin Emperor:
*"I now consume the people of Jianghuai—fifteen hundred thousand."*

The Jin Emperor was greatly alarmed.
Within two years,
Xu Xun alone received the *irresistible execution* decree,
and was posthumously honored as a *rightfully appointed* magistrate.
He declined the title, refusing to accept it.

The *Earthly Tribunals* reported to the *Heavenly Court*,
the *Heavenly Court* to the *Celestial Sovereign*,
the *Golden Threshold of Great Peace* to the *Jade Sovereign of the Later Saints*,
who dispatched an envoy to welcome Xu Xun.
He was granted *ascension in broad daylight*,
and his household was lifted from their homes to depart this world.

Thus, his killing was without blame,
and he earned *hidden merit*.
Again, if there are *refined spirits* or *malevolent spirits of calamity*
plaguing people,
binding them across generations without release,
or if they are *yin-precise* malevolent spirits,
causing illness and death among the populace,
unrest in homes,
and widespread suffering,
with no end in sight—
this follows the *符命* (divine mandate) of the *Supreme Venerable Lord Lao*,
using the *符* (talisman) to heal diseases,
and the afflicted recover.

Turning the *Heaven’s Gate* strike—
the *nine degrees* of the *irresistible execution*,
and saving those on duty for the *Six Jia* (days) and their corresponding *directing officials*,
as well as the *attendant officials*, *talisman scribes*, etc.—
urgently summon and compel them.

Thus, the healing talismans can transform into *spirits* or *officials*,
beheading those malevolent spirits,
and the illness is immediately cured.
Such deeds are *most exalted* in Heaven,
and the *Jade Sovereign* rejoices from afar.
Keep this secret—do not use it recklessly.

**Right: The Three *Yin-Functions* of the Six Jia.**
The remaining seven are in the Fourteenth Volume.

---
*End of the Golden Lock, Flowing Pearl Manual, Volume Seventeen.*

chunks.original_text: 中华总真大仙宰王方平张道陵赵升王长司命李仲甫茅盈许玉斧等系代撰述 中华仙人李淳风注 六甲阴功下 第四条阴功，老君曰：夫学道之士，於世修行之功，道法精能，符力成就。 忽有百姓及官人，被时行瘟毒，瘴气疾病，染者死伤，可以捻瘟鬼目，禹步九迹三步，配天关，指某方 某方是病人居处。 三度，然后与符帖，一一救之，立差。 其家有十人，三人四人五人见染，顿重欲死者，与符吞之，立差。 未病者带一符，令共一林坐卧，炁不相染易永，令病者得差不死，未病者不相染易。 一家有十人得十功，一家二十人得二十功，此符法阴功之大也。 秘之，勿妄传非人。 言功十条，此条要验，并后圣君授章，於六甲及六甲夫人。 章在《流珠上篇》。 后圣君告天师道陵：六甲之中，十条言功，治除瘟鬼救人条，其功甚大。 卿可自身及弟子，观世人中有被者，急与治之。 世人甚畏此疾，唧能救之，万民喜欢，皆言功力微妙，可以闻於上天。 一生身障之罪，应言消灭。 可宝而秘，勿传非人。 昔张天师未行此术之前，中国人民往彼故师求治，往彼者皆灭门，非咒术小小力之所能及也。 注：昔西国胡人师第三人，入中国咒此鬼，此鬼不伏，行炁冲杀其师。 第三人具《流珠中篇》具述，不复重耳。 其瘟鬼诀目，在左手第四指第三节。 瘟鬼诀目节上右边，欲近指甲，是瘟鬼刀之。 注：捻鬼目，鬼自伏走去。 捻鬼刀支，鬼三日而死。 大验。 昔左慈字元放，江东人。 善禁鬼。 魏文帝闻之，诏禁瘟鬼。 鬼知来哭而相谓曰：江东左君，以铜爪捻我目，我当去耳，不去欲以刀刺，我当即死。 大哭而俱去。 三日之内，宫中病者差，不病者永健，不相染易也。 太上老君授八蛮箓中，有治鬼符吏， 存之如图符，瘟鬼自走。 不走即死。 大验。
chunks.translated_text:
**Fourth Condition of the Six Jia Yin-Functions**

The Most High Lord of the Dao, the Sovereign of the Great Perfection, Zhai Wang Fangping, Zhang Daoling, Zhao Shengwang, the Long Official Li Zhongfu, Mao Ying, Xu Yufu, and others, compiled this in succession.
The Daoist Master Li Chunfeng annotated it.

The Lord Lao said:
*"Those who study the Dao and cultivate in the world—when their Daoist practices are refined and their talismanic power is perfected—
suddenly, if commoners or officials fall ill with epidemic pestilence, miasma-induced sickness, or contagious disease, causing death or injury among the afflicted,
one may pinch the *pestilence spirit’s eye*,
take nine *Yujia steps* in three strides,
align with the *Heaven’s Gate*,
and point toward the sick person’s dwelling in a certain direction—
three times.
Then, one may issue the talisman,
saving each afflicted person instantly.*

*If a household of ten has three, four, or five stricken, near death,
they may swallow the talisman and recover immediately.*

*Those not yet sick may wear one talisman,
ensuring none in the household contract the illness—
the sick recover, the healthy remain untainted.
A household of ten earns ten merits;
a household of twenty, twenty merits.
This is the supreme Yin-Function of the talismanic method.*

*Keep this secret—do not recklessly transmit it to the unworthy.*

*This is the tenth condition of merit.
Its efficacy is verified,
and the Later Sage Emperor bestowed this chapter
upon the Six Jia and their consorts.
The chapter is in *The Flowing Pearl: Upper Section*.*

*The Later Sage Emperor instructed the Heavenly Master Zhang Daoling:
‘Among the Six Jia, the tenth condition of merit—
the talisman that exorcises pestilence spirits and saves lives—
is of great power.
You and your disciples must observe the world:
if any are afflicted, treat them urgently.
The people fear this sickness greatly,
yet few can cure it.
When they see their lives saved, they will rejoice,
praising the marvelous efficacy—
worthy of Heaven’s hearing.
All sins of bodily obstruction shall be erased.
Guard this treasure carefully—do not reveal it to the unworthy.*

*Before Master Zhang Daoling practiced this method,
when Chinese people sought treatment from foreign masters,
those who went perished with their entire households—
not even minor exorcisms could save them.*

*Note: In the past, a third-generation foreign master entered China
and attempted to exorcise this spirit.
The spirit resisted,
and its qi struck him down.
This is fully recorded in *The Flowing Pearl: Middle Section*—
no need to repeat it here.*

*The pestilence spirit’s *eye* is located on the left hand’s fourth finger, third joint.
To the right of the joint, near the fingernail,
lies the *pestilence spirit’s blade*—
if struck, the spirit dies within three days.
This is highly verified.*

*In antiquity, Zuo Ci, styled Yuanfang, of Jiangdong,
was skilled in restraining spirits.
When Wei Wen Di heard of him, he commanded the exorcism of pestilence spirits.
The spirits, weeping, said to one another:
‘The Jiangdong Master Zuo will pinch our eyes with copper claws—
we must leave.
If we do not, he will strike us with his blade—
we will die immediately.’
They wept and departed together.
Within three days, all illnesses in the palace vanished,
the healthy remained untainted,
and none contracted the sickness.*

*The Most High Lord Lao bestowed the *Eight Barbarian Scriptures*,
which contain talismanic officials to subdue spirits.
Preserve them as in the diagram—
the pestilence spirits will flee.
If they do not flee, they will die.
This is highly verified."*

chunks.original_text: 能助阴功。 第五条阴功，老君曰：夫志心之人学道，本以慈心，济拯人物为本，制邪结正为心。 若有邪，正炁不行不降。 如能行符药，治邪妖之精，不干正。 且之心邪者，亦与一符两符，与吞正之。 如有久染邪疾，缠绵昏沈之者，十年五年，此是老精鬼魅，狐狸鼠獭之精，以符帖追斩之，无妨。 救一人是一功，诛精是二功。 诛之法以蹑地纪，飞天纲，各一遍。 散九迹禹步一遍，配衣七星，转天关，而指某乡里某人家。 三六九指，即存中下元六将军，在彼人宅上，放水放火，领兵三千万众，出如图到彼。 如中元三将军在流珠经图中，存到门捉鬼收诛之，大叫绕宅。 往往如此，三度思存，其精自死，疾病便差。 此阴功亦可为大，世人敬爱。 第六条阴功，修行之人功力已备，坐救千里，可能以符，救人征伐，带之於人身上，辟去刀剑，不伤害己者。 可取六甲日，呼六甲之神，步禹步三步九迹，奉以配衣，手指之三下，即给行军火符与带黠永不被贼伤害此身也。 如若是大将军求，欲为国杀灭彼贼众，即与之万胜神符与带之，能使刀剑不能伤害。 欲令带符军强为国者，可以步地纪九遍； 天纲三遍，散禹步九迹三遍，十二迹三遍，十五迹三遍，讫配衣，转天关，指之法，望彼贼之方，指之九过，捻彼方人刀支， 注：看贼在东方，木人刀支。 西方，金人刀支。 南方，火人刀支。 北方，水人刀支。 四季，土人刀支。 一云：亦随方配金水木火土用之，亦得。 此两法同前。 并随方用水洒之，彼众自败。 此法要秘，不可妄行。 前圣君出此法者，所以救有道。 之子难，并助有道之国难。 不可轻用，非子之命，立在须臾。 前圣君又告：雄黄赤色者，书大劫二符， 符在立法中，故不具。 又书入军符及六甲阴符六通，带之入兵，万不伤一。 符在《流珠中外篇》兵法中。 第七条阴功，天久雨不晴，百姓频被灾潦伤损，州县乡里人物漂损者，可以夜於隐密之室，蹑地纪三遍，飞天纲三遍，讫散为禹步九迹，至十二迹，十五迹，配衣，转天关，三指黑云暗处，三度讫，便出符牒彼社庙，限某日某时晴，即晴，捻龙目。 注：目在左手第一指第二节上左边近爪甲边，急捻之也。 第八条阴功，天久不雨，亢龙所为，百姓种植焦枯，田苗焦死，若此的非天命令旱者。 注：天令旱，不可妄为，损龙之命。 上天赐龙罪，应时天诛也。 前帖土地龙神所为不肯行雨者，即夜於中庭无人之处，步地纪天纲各三遍，散为禹步，三步九迹三遍，配衣，转天关，三指深水之溪潭。 注：潭中计合有龙有神灵水府之郎，即得当时应验雨下，速於水火之急也。 平旦书直日符，及九龙水符，连牒牒土地社庙， 注：古无城隍今事，须先言城隍神官，及地界社庙水府灵官，与直日神官集众，令便画时下雨。 急急如律令。 所由神官，速画时下雨，约限若干日内，通润百川，应口手之验。 老君曰：吾授此法，於世流行，以与修行志道之人，出世救人，以着大功。 救得一天下人物，皆得安心喜乐者也。 不可思议，承此功德，进益仙阶。 此第八条中一切圣真，皆久以留心志学，学得此法，积功易满，是径门得道也。 后圣君授告龙符三道，二道是六甲箓，中直日神之符，
chunks.translated_text:
The fifth *yin* virtue: The Most High Lord Lao said: *"Those who cultivate the Dao with a focused mind must take compassion as their foundation, rescuing and delivering all beings as their primary purpose, and subduing evil while establishing the rectified qi as their intent. If there is evil, the rectified qi cannot flow or descend. If one can employ talismans and medicines to treat malevolent spirits without harming the rectified, then even those whose hearts are steeped in evil may be given one or two talismans to swallow and purify them. For those afflicted with chronic evil illnesses—lingering, dim-witted, and enfeebled for ten or five years—these are the spirits of old *lao* (precocious) ghosts and demons, fox, weasel, or rat *jing* (essence-spirits). They may be pursued and beheaded with talismans without hesitation. Saving one person earns one virtue; exterminating a spirit earns two virtues.

The method for extermination involves reciting the *Di Ji* (Earth Memorization) once and the *Fei Tian Gang* (Flying Heaven Rope) once. Then, perform the *Yu Bu* (Flood Step) nine times, align with the *Pei Yi* (Configuring Garment) of the Seven Stars, turn the *Tian Guan* (Heavenly Lock), and point toward a specific village or household in a certain place. With three six nines (27) finger-pointings, summon the Six Generals of the Middle and Lower *Yuan* (Origins) to that person’s residence, commanding them to unleash water and fire, leading three hundred million troops as depicted in the diagram. If the Three Generals of the Middle *Yuan* are invoked from the *Liu Zhu Zhong Wai Pian* (Flowing Pearl Inner and Outer Chapters), they will arrive at the door to capture and exterminate the ghost, circling the residence with a great shout. Often, after three such invocations, the spirit will die, and the illness will abate. This *yin* virtue is also great, and the world will revere it.*

The sixth *yin* virtue: When a practitioner’s cultivation is complete, they may sit and rescue those thousands of miles away. With a talisman, they can save people in battle, binding it to a person’s body to ward off blades and swords, preventing harm. On a *Liu Jia* (Six Jia) day, one may invoke the *Liu Jia* deities, take three steps of the *Yu Bu* (nine traces), align with the *Pei Yi*, and point three times with the hand. This grants the *Xing Jun Huo Fu* (Marching Army Fire Talisman) and the *Dai Jue* (Bound Avoidance), ensuring the wearer will never be harmed by bandits. If a great general seeks to annihilate enemy forces for the state, they may be given the *Wan Sheng Shen Fu* (Ten-Thousand Victory Divine Talisman) to bind, rendering blades and swords powerless to harm.

For those commanding armies to strengthen the state, one may recite the *Di Ji* nine times, the *Fei Tian Gang* three times, disperse the *Yu Bu* in nine traces three times, twelve traces three times, and fifteen traces three times. Then align with the *Pei Yi*, turn the *Tian Guan*, and point toward the enemy’s direction nine times, pinching the *dao zhi* (claw support) of the person in that direction.
*Note: If the enemy is in the East (Wood), use the Wood-person *dao zhi*; West (Metal), Metal-person *dao zhi*; South (Fire), Fire-person *dao zhi*; North (Water), Water-person *dao zhi*; Seasons (Earth), Earth-person *dao zhi*. Alternatively, one may also correspond with the Five Phases (Metal, Water, Wood, Fire, Earth) as needed.*

These two methods are the same. Additionally, sprinkle water in accordance with the direction, and the enemy will self-destruct. This method must be kept secret and not used recklessly. The ancient sage-kings revealed this method to save those who cultivate the Dao, aiding them in times of difficulty and assisting Daoist states in peril. It must not be used lightly—without proper mandate, even a moment’s misuse is forbidden.

The ancient sage-kings further instructed: *"Realgar of a red hue—write the two *Da Jie* (Great Calamity) talismans, which are detailed in the *Li Fa* (Ritual Method). Also write the *Ru Jun Fu* (Entering Army Talisman) and the six *Liu Jia Yin Fu* (Six Jia Yin Talismans), binding them to the soldiers. In battle, they will suffer no injury for every ten thousand. These talismans are found in the *Liu Zhu Zhong Wai Pian* military methods."*

The seventh *yin* virtue: If the heavens endure prolonged rain without ceasing, and floods devastate the people—drowning villages, towns, and individuals—one may, in secret at night, recite the *Di Ji* three times and the *Fei Tian Gang* three times. Then disperse into the *Yu Bu* of nine traces, reaching twelve and fifteen traces, align with the *Pei Yi*, turn the *Tian Guan*, and point three times toward the darkest clouds. After three repetitions, issue a talisman to the local shrine, stipulating a specific day and hour for the rain to cease. If it does, pinch the *Long Mu* (Dragon’s Eye).
*Note: The eye is on the left side of the second joint of the left hand’s index finger, near the claw nail. Pinch it urgently.*

The eighth *yin* virtue: If the heavens withhold rain for too long, caused by the *Kang Long* (Proud Dragon), and crops wither and die—unless this drought is a heavenly decree—
*Note: If the drought is a heavenly command, do not act recklessly, lest you harm the Dragon’s mandate. The heavens punish the Dragon, and retribution follows naturally.*

If the drought is caused by the *Tu Di Long Shen* (Earthly Land Dragon Spirit) refusing to rain, one may, at night in an unoccupied courtyard, recite the *Di Ji* and *Fei Tian Gang* each three times, disperse into the *Yu Bu* of three steps and nine traces three times, align with the *Pei Yi*, turn the *Tian Guan*, and point three times toward a deep pool.
*Note: The pool must contain dragons or water deities, the officials of the Water Palace, to ensure immediate efficacy and swift rain as urgent as fire.*

At dawn, write the *Zhi Ri Fu* (Direct Day Talisman) and the *Jiu Long Shui Fu* (Nine Dragons Water Talisman), affixing them to the local shrine and land gods.
*Note: In ancient times, there were no *Cheng Huang* (City Gods); today, one must first invoke the City God officials and the land boundary shrine and water palace spirit officials, along with the Direct Day deity, to assemble the assembly and command the rain to fall at the appointed time. Urgently, as the law decrees. The deities will swiftly cause the rain to fall within the stipulated days, nourishing all rivers and streams, fulfilling the oath of hand and mouth.*

The Most High Lord Lao said: *"I have transmitted this method to the world, so that those who cultivate the Dao may save others and achieve great merit. Those who save all under heaven will attain peace and joy beyond measure. This virtue is unfathomable, and those who uphold it will ascend the ranks of the immortals. This eighth virtue is what all sages and true ones have long kept in mind for those who earnestly study. Mastering this method and accumulating merit leads directly to the Dao.

The later sage-kings further transmitted the three *Long Fu* (Dragon Talismans), including the second method of the *Liu Jia Lu* (Six Jia Scriptures) and the talisman of the *Zhi Ri Shen* (Direct Day Deity)."*

chunks.original_text: 注：在《六甲箓》中，用检取。 一符正告龙符、以依法行之，速於水火。 告龙符 右使龙诀，在左手第二指第一节是也。 太上老君曰：夫人学道之验者，未能知此使神役龙伏鬼之法，去道渐远，不可妄行。 其道佐佑人身。 吾见今时学道之人，唯以声像为道， 注：风见上古无为之教，今正入有为。 今人闻声，耳目俱虔诚，见像，心神俱起，信诚归心。 虽一时起善，不合道源，与道俱乖，徒修造弥天积山之功，身老自败而散。 故上智之人，不以声像为教。 故是小人嘻咔之功，徒行於世也。 以识性为德， 注：老君此言，训学者。 言当今之人，以强作知识之性真，名有为德之心，不是无为之德性也。 终老一生，虚以困苦求修。 如此之人，世间论万，无一成。 吾常叹此，故留阴功之条有十，此条为上。 昔舜帝时天旱一百日，帝命群臣乞雨。 五十日日中，曝人以渴乏，死者甚多，广遍九州，山热草死，石同火炭，不可立人。 忽有二仙人因行之，次叹曰：此等何人，为此苦热中作乐，何也。 对曰：请乞雨降。 仙人曰：雨是龙行，岂关人请。 官人对曰：请龙下降，乞行雨也。 仙人曰：子见龙识否。 曰：识。 子既道识龙，龙在何处，不请行雨。 於是官吏一时下拜，请示龙。 仙人忽尔，以手指一人脚，龙行虎步， 注：手指是转天关也。 脚为龙虎行步，即今之禹步。 行三遍讫，叱叱何不行雨。 是时龙走起拜，拜讫曰：天不许行雨一百八十日，某早两度潜行救人，皆被地府欲奏。 此度不敢行，行即被奏，奏闻上帝，必天符下诛龙身。 仙人即觅纸笔，书天符帖，帖社庙神官与龙同行雨。 当时社庙神龙，领得符帖，应时行雨，雨限一日内限足。 注：按限一日内足，此法太辛苦，龙神急切行雨，须以狂风白雨，吹拔树木。 此仙本意潜行雨，须令急速，恐天禁雨潜行，取遍罪任责龙。 如上帝不责龙，即得命。 如责龙，恐损也。 此时不责，为是仙人慈悲，救一切世界人之，故不责龙罪。 却得赏社庙及龙神八部，江海水府灵官众，得迁阶。 讫来一一谢此仙人。 今若得此道，但限三日五日内雨足，却为大功。 神龙人俱喜，依限雨足，须迁赏。 其功效决在法师，以量功举，可赏酒乐。 后有三会日，别表醮言功。 注：有一法不醮，但上言功章状，此不可也。 其三会日，是大醮日，合设将军史兵之日，如世天子命诸侯臣，案领三军相似。 每年事须春冬二时设，不可不为，不为违国之命令。 此三元箓，总取三元日醮，并与一状，与言功即得。 不必要须奏章事事，恐烦上帝道君。 第九条阴功，太上老君告方诸男真王方平、韩非正，女真李夫人、王夫人、紫微夫人等，七十二大真人日：夫世有志人，修行阴功，其大者莫过救人济贫，喜神理墓修坟。 注：理墓者，昔黄帝因巡於太山，路有埋尸，被水冲地以崩裂，中有数千露曝尸骨。 帝见命以众民，一一与收板隔地，以高山取不植之地，深孔而埋之，筑土高三尺，名之曰坟也。 因此之后，世人以学黄帝。 此埋葬法，四片大板，隔四边土，一片大板，当上盖之，此是造冢之法也。 乃至今人以棺器为板椁，转加新奇，号曰墓。 后梦中有一千余人来见，谢言曰：陛下治人有道，治鬼有德，今臣某等约有一千七百余人，伏蒙陛下赐天恩，为屋盖着，得免某等曝露尸骨，某等昨日已上天曹通辞，言蒙陛下赐恩，移埋尸骨之功，天曹与为倍功之数。
chunks.translated_text:
「Annotation: Within the *Six Jia Scriptures*, the method is selected as follows: One talisman is used to summon the Dragon Talismans, in accordance with the law, swiftly as water and fire. The Dragon Talisman is invoked by the *Long Jue* (Dragon Decision), located on the left hand’s second finger at its first joint.

The Most High Lord Lao said: *"Those who earnestly cultivate the Dao and seek verification must first understand this method of employing the Way to subdue dragons and enslave ghosts. Those who fail to grasp it will drift ever farther from the Dao, and must not presume to practice it. This method aids and assists the human body. I observe that in the present age, those who study the Dao merely take sound and image as the Dao.

Annotation: The wind carries the teachings of the ancient *Wu Wei* (Non-Action) Dao; now, they have entered the realm of *You Wei* (Action).

Nowadays, when people hear the Dao’s teachings, their ears and eyes are filled with devotion, and when they see its symbols, their hearts and spirits rise in faith. Though they may briefly awaken to goodness, their actions do not align with the Dao’s source, nor with the Dao itself. They merely labor at constructing mountains of merit that span the skies, only to exhaust themselves in vain and dissipate their efforts. Thus, the truly wise do not take sound and image as their instruction.

This is the hollow merit of the petty-minded, who vainly practice in the world. To recognize one’s true nature as *virtue* (德),—

Annotation: Lord Lao’s words here instruct the students, stating that in the present age, people mistake the forced cultivation of knowledge and true nature as the heart of *You Wei* (Action) virtue, rather than the natural virtue of *Wu Wei* (Non-Action). Throughout their lives, they exhaust themselves in futile, arduous striving. Such people, though the world may count them by the ten-thousand, will not achieve a single success. I often lament this, hence I have left ten conditions of hidden merit, and this is the foremost.

In the time of the ancient sage-king Shun, there was a drought lasting one hundred days. The emperor commanded his ministers to pray for rain. After fifty days, the sun’s midday heat scorched people with thirst and want, and many died—spread across all nine regions, with mountains blazing, grasses withering, and stones glowing like embers, making it unbearable for people to stand. Suddenly, two immortals arrived, and one sighed: *"What kind of people are these, finding joy in such agonizing heat? Why?"*

The other replied: *"Let us pray for rain to descend."*

The immortal said: *"Rain is the dragon’s movement; why should it concern your prayers?"*

The official answered: *"We pray that the dragon descends and moves to bring rain."*

The immortal asked: *"Do you recognize the dragon?"*

The official said: *"I recognize it."*

The immortal then said: *"Since you recognize the dragon, where is it? Why do you pray for its rain?"*

At this, the officials knelt in unison, asking the immortal to indicate the dragon’s whereabouts. The immortal suddenly pointed at one man’s foot, and the dragon moved with tiger-like strides—

Annotation: The act of pointing with the hand is the turning of the Celestial Gate.

The man’s foot became the dragon’s and tiger’s steps, resembling the *Wu Bu* (Avoiding Steps) of today. After three strides, the immortal shouted: *"Why does the dragon not move to bring rain?"*

At that moment, the dragon bowed and said: *"The Celestial Sovereign forbids rain for one hundred and eighty days. I have already twice secretly brought rain to save people, but both times I was summoned by the Underworld to report. This time, I dare not move, for if I do, I will be summoned, and my transgression will be heard by the Supreme Deity. The Celestial Talisman will descend to punish my body as a dragon."*

The immortal immediately sought paper and brush, writing a Celestial Talisman decree. He affixed it to the shrine deities and the dragon, commanding them to bring rain together. At that time, the shrine deities and the dragon, having received the decree, brought rain as ordered, and the limit was fulfilled within one day.

Annotation: Though the limit was fulfilled within one day, this method is too harsh. The dragon and deities, in their urgency to bring rain, must use violent winds and torrential downpours, uprooting trees. The immortal’s original intent was to secretly bring rain, but fearing that the Celestial Sovereign might forbid it and assign all the blame to the dragon, he ordered the storm to be swift. If the Celestial Sovereign did not punish the dragon, it would be spared. If he did punish it, the immortal feared damage to the dragon. At that time, the dragon was not punished, which was due to the immortal’s compassion, saving all beings in the world. Thus, the Celestial Sovereign did not blame the dragon. Instead, he rewarded the shrine deities, the dragon deities, and the eight departments of the river and sea spirits, granting them promotions. From then on, all of them thanked the immortal one by one.

Now, if one obtains this method, the rain limit is set within three to five days, and this is already considered a great merit. Both the deities and the people rejoice, and according to the limit, the rain will be fulfilled, and promotions will follow. The merit’s efficacy lies with the Daoist master, who assesses the merit and may bestow rewards of wine and music.

Later, there are three *Hui* (Assembly) days, where separate offerings are made to declare the merit’s efficacy.

Annotation: There is a method that does not require offerings; one simply submits the merit declaration and petition. This is not permissible. The three Assembly days are the days of the grand *Jiao* (Offering), when one must set up generals, officials, and soldiers, as if the world’s emperor commands his vassals and ministers, overseeing the three armies in a similar manner. Each year, these rites must be performed in spring and winter; failure to do so violates the imperial command. This is the *San Yuan Lu* (Three Primordial Scriptures), which takes the Three Primordial days for the offering, along with one petition and merit declaration. It is not necessary to submit all petitions and documents, lest they trouble the Supreme Deity and Lord of the Dao.

The ninth condition of hidden merit: The Most High Lord Lao instructed the male *Zhen Ren* (True Persons) like *Zhen Wang* (True King) Fang Ping and Han Fei Zheng, and the female *Zhen Ren* like Li the Lady, Wang the Lady, and the Lady of *Zi Wei* (Purple Micro), among the seventy-two great *Zhen Ren*, saying: *"In the world, those who earnestly cultivate hidden merit must strive for the greatest deeds—none surpass saving people and aiding the poor, nor honoring the spirits of the dead and repairing tombs.

Annotation: The honoring of tombs refers to the ancient Yellow Emperor, who during his inspection of Mount Tai encountered a buried corpse whose coffin had been washed away by water, causing the earth to collapse and expose thousands of skeletal remains. The emperor, moved by the suffering of the common people, had them all collected and placed between four large boards, with the space taken from an uninhabited highland and buried in a deep pit. He then built a mound of earth three feet high, naming it a *fen* (tomb). After this, people followed the Yellow Emperor’s example. This burial method involved four large boards, isolating the four sides of the earth, and one large board placed above as a cover—this was the method of constructing tombs. Even to this day, people use coffins as boards and *guo* (outer coffins), adding new embellishments and calling them *mu* (graves).

In his dreams, the emperor saw over a thousand people come to thank him, saying: *"Your Majesty governs the living with the Dao and the dead with virtue. Now, we, your subjects—over a thousand seven hundred in number—have been granted your celestial mercy. You provided shelter for our exposed bones, and we have already yesterday petitioned the Celestial Bureau, stating that we were blessed by your Majesty’s mercy in relocating and burying our remains. The Bureau has rewarded your Majesty’s deeds with double merit."*」

The later sage-kings further transmitted the three *Long Fu* (Dragon Talismans), including the second method of the *Liu Jia Lu* (Six Jia Scriptures) and the talisman of the *Zhi Ri Shen* (Direct Day Deity)."*

chunks.original_text: 从此之后，四十五年，白日上升云天，当为上等真仙也。 后果如所言。 获感通神。 注：《黄帝本章》出从立冢深埋死人之法，教世。 世人学之，后以功弥满世界，神鬼喜欢。 人死之后，或有精魂强智者，得为天神、地神、社神、稷神，不强者为鬼。 鬼中亦有上中下三等之号。 上等鬼以福佑人善行，报人之德。 中等鬼不以福佑人，亦不以祸加人。 如此二等，早得托生，於人天之报，名善鬼。 太上喜念之，不令受道法箓之人所损，恐其鬼失生天之路。 下等鬼常以行祸害祟人，行疾病於人世，太上后圣二君大嗔责之，常令受道之人，以法诀收而诛之。 一被道科之后，鬼魂入北帝幽岳，系连年不决断，纵得诀断，不得人身托生。 唯淮天科，以托生为毒虫蛇蝎之类，百死十生，不复人身。 人龙庆贺，百川灵兽献上瑞图，四海龙鳞进於珠玉，岂非帝行阴功之德感通也。 又老君告苦行真人郭晋卿等曰： 卿行苦行救人，莫过种福，果熟於后人，赐宝赐薪，给於见乏，如此之功，可大可验，得道也。 又以烧炼铜铁，而作假色金银，须薄取半直， 注：半直，真金十贯一两，假色者本是铜铁，而一两可於半中取半，则二千五百价一两。 而上亦屈於本人，不可妄为。 而此法是前圣后圣，教有道之士为之者，供自身衣粮，及家口等。
chunks.translated_text:
From this point onward, forty-five years passed, and the sun ascended into the clouds of heaven by day—he was indeed to become a supreme true immortal. Later, as foretold, he attained divine communion.

**Annotation:** *Huangdi’s Original Chapter* records the method of erecting tombs and burying the dead to teach the world. When people learned this, their merit spread across the world, delighting gods and ghosts. After death, some with strong and wise spirits became celestial deities, earth deities, deities of the soil, or deities of grain, while the weaker became ghosts. Among ghosts, there were three ranks: superior, middle, and inferior.

The superior ghosts bestow blessings upon the virtuous and repay human kindness. The middle ghosts neither bless nor harm. These two ranks, if they attain rebirth early, are called *shan gui* (benevolent ghosts) in the retribution of human and heavenly realms. The Most High cherished them, forbidding those who received Daoist precepts from harming them, lest they lose the path to heavenly rebirth.

The inferior ghosts, however, constantly bring calamity, misfortune, and disease to the world. The Most High and the Sage Lords were enraged and often commanded Daoists to subdue and exterminate them with spells. Once subjected to Daoist judgment, their spirits were bound to the Northern Emperor’s dark and desolate peaks, imprisoned for years without resolution. Even if released, they could not be reborn as humans. Only those judged by the *Huai Tian* (Mars) were condemned to be reborn as venomous creatures—centipedes, scorpions, and snakes—dying a hundred times before being reborn once, never again as humans.

When the human realm rejoiced, the hundred rivers and spiritual beasts presented auspicious diagrams, while the four seas’ dragons offered pearls and jade—was this not the virtue and divine communion of the Emperor’s hidden deeds?

Again, the Celestial Worthy instructed the ascetic practitioners of bitter austerity, such as Guo Jinqing, saying: *"Your austerities save others, none greater than sowing merit. Its fruits will benefit future generations. I grant you treasures and firewood when you are in need—such deeds are vast and verifiable, leading to the Dao."*

Moreover, he taught the forging of copper and iron into counterfeit gold and silver, taking only half the price—**Annotation:** *Half the price* means that genuine gold is worth ten *guan* per *liang* (ounce), but since counterfeit gold is made of copper or iron, one *liang* could be sold for half its value, yielding 2,500 in profit per *liang*. Yet even this, the Sage Lords permitted only for the practitioner’s own sustenance—clothing, food, and household needs—and forbade reckless excess. This method was taught by the Sage Lords of old and new to those on the Daoist path, allowing them to provide for themselves and their families.

chunks.translated_text:
Moreover, they also used cloth and silk to make garments, feigning lost clothing along the way to give alms to the poor and the sick, thereby seeking the hidden virtue of *yin-de* (meritorious deeds unseen by others). In the past, several *zhenren* (perfected ones) practiced such deeds. This provided for their own families while also rescuing the poor and the sick—another great merit.

One must not deceive the world by falsely claiming such actions as true gold, nor should one exploit the faithful by inflating the value of treasures and rare artifacts to mislead honest people. Such crimes are grave and cannot be redeemed by seeking hidden merit. **Beware.**

**Annotation:** In the past, *Yin Changsheng* (a Daoist adept) would feign lost money to aid the destitute, thereby earning hidden merit through such deeds. Today, some falsely claim this Daoist method, deceiving common folk by saying, *"This forged gold, when refined, becomes an elixir—unmatched in the world, worthy of immortals’ alchemy."* Yet how could immortals engage in such worldly deceit?

Furthermore, immortals all practice methods of lightening the body, allowing them to transcend physical form at will. They consume elixirs of metals and minerals to achieve levitation—such claims are utterly baseless.

**The Tenth Principle of *Yin-Function* (Hidden Merit):**
A discourse on how *zhenren* (perfected ones) and their disciples practice hidden merit and its virtues.

chunks.original_text: 中华总真大仙宰王方平张道陵赵升王长司命李仲甫茅盈许玉斧等系代撰述 中华仙人李淳风注 六甲阴功下之下 老君告东来子曰： 注：东来子，是禹之子。 学道不行阴功，唯行阳功，功心巧好，造楼於空野之地，上像道家形影，欲将此为一生之德，欲乘此功德，图身得道。 称我造十万余功，合得大仙。 一旦，忽二冥使追赴太山门下，被问何因造台，妄杀生命，祭於川野之鬼，牛猪羊驴数十头疋而言汝也。 汝答承伏杀他，我即出汝之罪。 若不伏，即当禁身责问。 为汝父理水有功，今为太极真人，不可咒受杀生之罪。 我当为汝，减父之福，以当救汝得放，当归世俗，作阴功过度他生命，即得成人，百劫千生，不复来觅命也。 来子应曰：承伏。 毕，推官果与谘太山君，君放即还死，经七日而活。 活后常以直心，不害物命，常以己财帛，赎合死者生命，放之无限，往往如此。 或以人禁系鸟兽，常行欢心令放。 或以施食及衣，於禁狱之囚。 如此三十年间，先杀者牛羊猪驴马畜等，总托生为人，永无怨对。 如此之小功着，上感太上老君，示见正说阴功，行步履天地纲纪之法，施此六甲之功。 一旦忽通神威，感天地，惊动人物仙人也，老君再降，赐告大阴功。 卿立身，先是好起楼台，杀生祭祀神鬼，将此以欲治身求真。 具前注。 既因冥使告知，今心知悔过，今当正教子着阴功。 功之有十，一则服六甲真符，以治身疾。 二则真心，不损不害，不杀不伤，不邪不淫， 注：自有妻妾，不合妄更侵淫他人也。 不妄不佞不盗，去九等之恶，为九等之善。 一慈，二孝，三心有敬，四身有礼，五行仁德，六少言语，七不为人之先， 己虽大於彼人，亦须先让他为先，不损於己之德也。 八不妄害鬼神，九常怀学道，得道后救度一切人物。 注：昔严清常以烧炭，卖与贫者，减三钱四钱一秤，或以见乏者，与之一秤二秤。 如此三十余年，一旦有玉女下授十卷符箓，六甲为先。 令清跪受，一一分付，教以修行六甲符。 清对曰：清不解书。 玉女曰：犹解九等阴功，何不读书学书，取识文字，书但得成，即得。 於是清便读史书，不识文字，玉女教之。 不能书，玉女教写。 如此三年成，书学满腹，问无不知，圣也。 常行救治百姓疾病之功，传出弟子，皆以治病为事，时号曰严君之道。 后圣君告天师曰：卿为师行教弟子，行阴功者有二。 注：一师须明弟子心，二弟子孝於师。 一师先明弟子，有心无心，有信无信。 注：今时多有弟子，有口无心。 若此等之人，切不得轻信传事。 须信重他心，不可顿辨得。 辨得即师亦无失，即可具传小法一阶。 若是志心好乐仙道，日夜思道乐真，丹恳供办，师量事依科中，一一减信，以行阴功。 二弟子日夜知信心真直，常阴念道孝师，师亦感通，常示见弟子。 弟子呼存行用立验，应於弟子心口，所为皆遂，除三逆之外，随意所欲。 注：一不逆君言，二不逆父语，三不逆师教。 此三条是天师注授王长赵升语诀，行告弟子。 又告天师曰：夫与人阴启至道至尊得达者，是名心愿启善利人，是名阴功，而名行阴德，天常善之，后子孙继代，仕宦不绝。 注：善启救病，拔度灾厄，但行善事，凶恶不为，常心行济国救人，故名善事，而功德成就，白日升仙也。
chunks.translated_text:
「The **Grand Daoist Sage** of the **Central Realm**, **Zaiwang** of the **Great Perfection**, **Zhang Daoling**, **Zhao Sheng**, **Wang Chang** (the **Master of Command**), **Li Zhongfu**, **Mao Ying**, **Xu Yufu**, and others, were all later disciples who compiled and expounded upon the teachings. The **Daoist Sage** **Li Chunfeng** annotated them. Below, the **Six Jia** (注: *Six Jia* refers to the six celestial stems, 甲,乙,丙,丁,戊,己, symbolizing a cycle of Daoist practices) **Yin-Function** (Hidden Merit) is discussed.

**Old Lord** (注: *Old Lord*, 老君, refers to **Laozi**, the revered Daoist sage and patriarch) instructed **Donglai Zi** (注: *Donglai Zi*, 東來子, is **Yu the Great’s** son):

*"Donglai Zi, you learned the Dao but did not practice **Yin-Function** (Hidden Merit), only **Yang-Function** (Manifest Virtue). Your craftsmanship was clever and refined—you built a tower in an empty wilderness, carving images of Daoist figures upon it, intending this as your lifelong virtue. You sought to rely on these merits to attain the Dao and transcendence. You claim that I have crafted over ten thousand merits for you, sufficient to make you a **Great Sage** (大仙).

One day, suddenly, two **Ming Officials** (注: *Ming Officials*, 二冥使, are underworld judges or messengers) summoned you to the **Gate of Tai Mountain** (太山門下), questioning why you constructed the tower, slaughtered living beings, and sacrificed them to spirits and ghosts in the rivers and wilds—countless oxen, pigs, sheep, donkeys, and other beasts. They said to you: *'Confess your crimes, or we shall bind your body and interrogate you further.'*

You replied: *'I submit to my transgressions and accept the blame for others.'* Then, I pardoned your offense.

But if you had not submitted, you would have been bound and punished. Your father had merit for managing the waters, now you are a **Tai Ji Perfected One** (太極真人), and cannot be cursed to bear the sin of killing. I shall reduce your father’s blessings to atone for your salvation, allowing you to return to the mortal world. If you now practice **Yin-Function** (Hidden Merit) to an extent surpassing others’ lifespans, you shall attain **perfected humanity** (成人), and for countless kalpas and lifetimes, you will no longer be sought by the underworld for retribution.

**Donglai Zi** responded: *'I submit.'*

Upon completion, the **Ming Official** truly consulted with **Tai Mountain Lord** (太山君), who released you from death, and you revived after seven days.

Afterward, you always acted with sincerity, never harming living beings. You frequently used your own wealth to redeem the lives of the deceased, liberating them without limit. You often did this.

Or, when people were imprisoned and bound, you would joyfully release them. Or, you would give food and clothing to those in jail.

For thirty years, those you had previously killed—oxen, sheep, pigs, donkeys, horses, and other livestock—all took rebirth as humans, forever free of resentment.

Because of these minor merits, you were favored by **Tai Shang Laozi** (太上老君), who revealed the **true teachings of Yin-Function** (Hidden Merit) to you, instructing you in the **steps of the Dao’s celestial principles** (天地纲纪之法) and granting you the **Six Jia merits** (六甲之功).

One day, suddenly, your **divine influence** (通神威) resonated with the heavens and earth, startling both mortals and immortals. **Old Lord** descended again, bestowing upon you the **Great Yin-Function** (大阴功).

You said: *'I have always been fond of constructing towers and altars, killing living beings to sacrifice to spirits and ghosts, intending this as a means to refine my body and seek the Dao.'*

*(As recounted earlier.)*

Now that the **Ming Officials** have informed you, you must reflect and repent. I shall now properly instruct you in **Yin-Function** (Hidden Merit). There are ten merits:

1. **Wearing the Six Jia True Talisman** (服六甲真符) to heal bodily ailments.
2. **True-heartedness** (真心), not causing harm or injury, not killing or wounding, not acting deceitfully or lustfully. *(注: Even if you have wives and concubines, do not arbitrarily change or defile others.)*
3. **Avoiding falsehood, flattery, and theft**, abandoning the nine levels of evil and cultivating the nine levels of good.
   - *One: Benevolence (慈),*
   - *Two: Filial piety (孝),*
   - *Three: Reverence in heart (心有敬),*
   - *Four: Dignity in form (身有礼),*
   - *Five: Practicing virtue (行仁德),*
   - *Six: Sparing speech (少言语),*
   - *Seven: Not acting before others (不为人之先).*
     - *Even if you are greater than others, you must yield and let them act first, so as not to diminish your own virtue (德).*
   - *Eight: Not harming spirits and ghosts unjustly (不妄害鬼神),*
   - *Nine: Always cherishing the Dao (常怀学道).*
4. **After attaining the Dao**, saving all beings.

*(注: **Yan Qing** (昔嚴清) once reduced the weight of charcoal by three or four coins per measure when selling it to the poor, or gave one or two measures to those in need. For over thirty years, one day a **Jade Maiden** (玉女) descended to bestow ten volumes of talismans and scriptures, beginning with the **Six Jia**. She commanded **Yan Qing** to kneel and receive them, explaining each one and teaching him to cultivate the **Six Jia Talismans**. **Yan Qing** replied: *'I do not understand scriptures.'* The **Jade Maiden** said: *'You already understand the nine levels of Yin-Function (Hidden Merit), so why not study and learn to recognize the characters? Once you grasp the scriptures, you will succeed.'*

Thus, **Yan Qing** began reading history books. Though he did not recognize the characters, the **Jade Maiden** taught him. Unable to write, she taught him calligraphy. In three years, he mastered the scriptures, filling his mind with knowledge, and none could question him—he was a sage. He frequently practiced the merit of healing the people’s illnesses and passed this on to his disciples, who all took healing as their practice. At the time, it was called **Yan Jun’s Dao** (嚴君之道).

Later, the **Holy Sage** (聖君) informed the **Heavenly Master** (天師):

*'You instruct your disciples in practicing Yin-Function (Hidden Merit), which has two essentials:*
   - *(注: One, the teacher must discern the disciple’s sincerity; two, the disciple must be filial to the teacher.)*
   - *One: The teacher must first discern the disciple—whether they have sincerity or not, faith or not. *(注: In this age, many disciples have empty words but no sincerity. Such people must not be lightly trusted to pass on teachings.)* You must weigh their sincerity carefully; do not hastily judge them. If you judge them accurately, the teacher will not err, and you may then impart a minor stage of the Dao’s methods. If the disciple has a resolute heart and delights in the Dao, day and night thinking of the Dao and rejoicing in its truth, earnestly offering supplies, the teacher will measure their deeds according to the scriptures, reducing their faults to guide them in practicing Yin-Function (Hidden Merit).*
   - *Two: The disciple must always know the teacher’s sincerity is true and upright, secretly invoking the Dao to honor the teacher. The teacher, in turn, will be moved and often reveal themselves to the disciple. The disciple will call upon the teacher, and the teacher will respond in their heart and mind, fulfilling all their deeds—except for the three rebellions. *(注: One, not rebelling against the sovereign’s words; two, not rebelling against the father’s instructions; three, not rebelling against the teacher’s guidance.)* These three prohibitions are the **Heavenly Master’s** instructions to **Wang Chang** and **Zhao Sheng**, passed on to disciples.*

*Again, the **Heavenly Master** said: 'He who secretly guides others to attain the Dao’s highest truths and honors, is said to have a **heart of benevolent enlightenment** (心願啓善利人), known as **Yin-Function** (Hidden Merit), and as **practicing Yin-Virtue** (行阴德). The heavens reward such deeds, and their descendants will inherit this virtue through generations, never ceasing to hold official positions. *(注: If you guide others in good deeds—such as healing illnesses, delivering them from calamities and misfortunes—always act with sincerity, never committing evil, and frequently practice benevolence to save the nation and people, then your merits will be fulfilled, and you will ascend to immortality in broad daylight.)*'*

chunks.original_text: 若启愿凶，损物害人，若启至道至尊，虽应，终不大通行。 再启得行，害人损物，是名阴谋，而名行阴贼，天常恶之，后子孙必有疾绝。 注：纵有子孙不绝，亦足疾病，无官无职，而为下民也。 吾此言再授卿，知令卿须系代为师，而教后学。 勿为恶愿，皆须常善言。 注：声教为善言，心行为善愿也。 善愿为上。 老君告北斗真公曰：夫人行阴启， 注：启善言善愿，愿除妖辟恶，口舌厄疾，中有人鬼名，不欲人闻者，可以阴启，奏低小声读之，勿令外人闻。 闻恐为所说，入一人之耳，出百人之口，不可令闻，为天曹未知，人道妄传，以为怨对，神鬼所知，恐於云中及关天门三所，为势力神鬼所截，关奏不允达於太上御前，诺下天曹下。 卿须急与关奏，上玉皇。 若待地府二符俱来，而被怨对，怨炁及阴官地府故炁，共为所截，不御达也。 卿须勿待阴阳二符。 注：符史也。 夫人以顺事闲章表关奏之言，音调声律，言语高响，欲人所知。 即集地府及法箓中史兵众，差阴阳神六甲中二直符，先启北斗君，北斗君转启关奏君，方始达章於天师君。 老君诗天师君号释师，佛呼帝释是也。 后圣政此位为天师，姓张，名陵。 天师君署讫，只御达上太上御前中理。 恐为天地水三官，妄以前奏云：某乙奏章，有妄太上无极大道。 太上老君、后圣玉皇上道君等二圣，不与允达顺。 慎之。 所以置於阴启奏关之科。 老君告妙行真人曰： 注：妙行有八人，正妙行姓真，名定光。 夫人学知十等阴功，於人物之者，得此门长存行之，不逾五六年间，便得神道与通。 得通神之后，唯以善救人物。 人物积受其恩，渐闻天曹，事与关奏太上。 太上喜之，一一听与，御诺天司，便注言功於仙籍。 功满三千，太上给以十直仙童十人， 注：日得一人，玉童二人，玉女真官一人，从官随日人数直符二人。 十二直玉女十二人， 注：日二，玉女直一人，与录阴功一人，与外人物关奏行通，启章表之事闻天曹，便转与闻，奏太上御前。 真官一人， 注：甲子即王文卿，乙丑龙季卿，六甲中用，周而复始，无极於六甲中。 从官随日人数当直，以依日呼其名，而使之应道，存而所用，无犯也。 注：使应道即无所犯。 不应道使之，即犯科律也。 直符二人。 注：当行直日之符，以救人物之疾害也。 当直修行六甲阴功之人，轮转无阙，又无犯者。 注：犯者妄行，用害人物，妄言惑人，令以淫祀，六甲阴功玉女、六甲君、北斗君大嗔恶之，反以为祸祸人。 此名狐假虎威之义，惑人求财，其罪两及。 一为惑人大罪，二被惑人之心身，本无厄疾，妄於北斗所求，即云有厄，此妄天地之罪。 被转天关之神，嗔人淫祀，因转关之。 次便转手指本生宿星，此人便却招罪，受病减算，注入邪道。 如实有灾厄，修行亦须依北斗仪，不得妄为，亦是有犯也。 一一计得，阴功满便仙也。 后圣君告天师曰：六甲之阴功，可大功也。 夫天地间万神，皆六甲君之部使也。 使之功理正直，行於天地间，人物慈心爱敬，施法惠恩流福，润及於苍生，而称善行用，神灵有功。 不杀不害，不妖不妄，此名阴福流济， 注：或符术治病，或决龙行雨，千州万乡，济润邦国，百姓欢泰，人物俱安，其功可大功也。
chunks.translated_text:
If one secretly guides others toward evil, harming people and things, even if they guide them to the Dao’s highest truths and honors, it will never truly prevail. If they secretly guide others to act harmfully, damaging people and things, this is called **Yin-Plotting**, and is known as **practicing Yin-Treason** (行阴贼). The heavens abhor such deeds, and their descendants will surely suffer early deaths. *(Note: Even if descendants do not perish, they will still suffer illness, holding no office nor rank, and will be commoners.)*

I now pass this teaching to you again, knowing you must act as a substitute teacher and instruct future generations. Do not harbor evil intentions—always speak with benevolence. *(Note: Benevolent speech is the voice of teaching; benevolent intentions are the heart’s practice.)* Benevolent intentions are supreme.

The **Celestial Master** told the **True Lord of the Northern Dipper**: "When people secretly guide others, *(Note: guiding with benevolent speech and intentions, wishing to remove demons, evil spirits, and calamities of speech and illness—names unknown to mortals—one may secretly guide them, reciting softly and quietly so as not to be heard by outsiders. If heard, they may be spoken of by one person and spread by a hundred. It must not be heard, lest the Heavenly Tribunals remain unaware, and human rumors falsely transmit it as grievance. The spirits and gods know, fearing that in the clouds or at the Heavenly Gate’s three barriers, they may be intercepted by powerful spirits and gods. The Heavenly Gate’s petitions will not be permitted to reach the **Supreme Sovereign’s** presence, and the decree will descend to the Heavenly Tribunals.)* You must urgently petition the Heavenly Gate and address the **Jade Emperor**. If you wait for both the **Yin** and **Yang** talismans to arrive, you will be accused of grievance, and the **Yin Officials** and **Earthly Tribunals** will intercept you, preventing your petition from reaching the **Supreme Sovereign’s** presence. You must not wait for the **Yin** and **Yang** talismans. *(Note: Talismans are also called **Shi**.)*

When people use proper petitions, idle memorials, and Heavenly Gate petitions, their tone, rhythm, and resonant speech are meant to be known by others. They then gather the **Earthly Tribunals’** and **Legal Talisman** armies, dispatching the **Yin-Yang Gods** of the **Six Jia** with two **Direct Talismans**, first petitioning the **Lord of the Northern Dipper**, who then relays it to the **Heavenly Gate’s** petitioner, only then reaching the **Celestial Master**. The **Celestial Master** is called **Release Teacher** in the **Laozi’s** poem, which the Buddha refers to as **Indra**. The later sage’s title is **Celestial Master**, surnamed **Zhang**, named **Ling**. After the **Celestial Master’s** decree is issued, it is directly conveyed to the **Supreme Sovereign’s** presence. Beware of the **Three Officials of Heaven, Earth, and Water** falsely petitioning before the **Supreme Sovereign**, claiming: ‘So-and-so’s memorial contains falsehoods against the **Supreme Sovereign’s** boundless Dao.’ The **Supreme Sovereign, Laozi**, and the **Jade Emperor, the Way-Bearing Sovereign**, will not permit such petitions to pass. Be cautious. This is why the **Yin-Petition** to the **Heavenly Gate** exists.

The **Celestial Master** told the **True Person of Marvelous Conduct** *(Note: There are eight **Marvelous Conduct** figures; the true **Marvelous Conduct** bears the surname **Zhen**, named **Dingguang**):* "When people study and understand the **Ten Grades of Yin-Function** and apply them to others, they will long endure in this practice. Within five or six years, they will attain **Divine Communication** and **Transcendence**. After achieving **Divine Communication**, they must only act benevolently to save others. As people accumulate their kindness, they will gradually be heard by the **Heavenly Tribunals**, and their petitions will reach the **Heavenly Gate** and the **Supreme Sovereign**. The **Supreme Sovereign** will rejoice and grant each petition, decreeing to the **Heavenly Officials**, who will then record their merits in the **Immortal Register**. When their merits reach three thousand, the **Supreme Sovereign** will bestow ten **Direct Immortal Children**, *(Note: one per day, two **Jade Boys**, one **Jade Girl Official**, and two **Attendant Officials** corresponding to the number of days’ **Direct Talismans**.)* twelve **Direct Jade Girls**, *(Note: two per day, one **Jade Girl Official**, one to record **Yin-Function**, and one to petition the **Heavenly Gate** for matters concerning mortals and petitions to the **Heavenly Tribunals**.)* one **True Official**, *(Note: **Jiazi** is **Wang Wenqing**, **Yichou** is **Long Jiqing**; these are used cyclically within the **Six Jia**, repeating endlessly without bound.)* and **Attendant Officials** corresponding to the number of days’ **Direct Talismans**, summoned by name according to the day to fulfill their duties without transgression. *(Note: Summoning them to fulfill their duties means no transgression. If not summoned to fulfill their duties, it is a violation of the laws.)* two **Direct Talismans**. *(Note: The talismans for the day’s duties are used to save others from calamities and harm.)* The person performing the **Six Jia Yin-Function** duties rotates endlessly without interruption, and none shall transgress. *(Note: Transgressors act falsely, harming others, deceiving people, and leading them to licentious worship. The **Six Jia Yin-Function Jade Girls**, the **Six Jia Lords**, and the **Northern Dipper Lord** will greatly resent this, turning it into misfortune for the transgressor. This is the meaning of **‘the fox assuming the tiger’s威’**—deceiving others for gain. The crime is twofold: first, the great crime of deceiving others; second, the harm done to the deceived person’s body and mind. Though originally free from calamity, they falsely petition the **Northern Dipper**, claiming misfortune, which is a false accusation against Heaven and Earth. The gods of the **Heavenly Gate** resent licentious worship and thus intercept the petition. Next, the finger-star of their original birth is implicated, and the person will instead incur guilt, suffer reduced lifespan, and be consigned to an evil path. If there is genuine calamity, one must still follow the **Northern Dipper’s** rites—any deviation is also transgression. Each offense is calculated, and when **Yin-Function** is complete, one ascends as an immortal.)"

The **Later Sage** told the **Celestial Master**: "The **Six Jia’s Yin-Function** can achieve great merit. All ten thousand gods between Heaven and Earth are the **Six Jia Lords’** subordinates. If they act with righteousness and propriety, benefiting mortals with compassion and reverence, their laws and blessings flow like恩福, nourishing the common people, and their deeds are called **benevolent and efficacious**. They neither kill nor harm, neither practice sorcery nor falsity—this is called **Yin-Blessings flowing to save**, *(Note: whether through talismanic healing or invoking dragons to bring rain, benefiting ten thousand towns and villages, nourishing the nation, and bringing joy to the people—all are at peace, and their merit is great.)*

chunks.original_text: 千州万民欢泰，功积山岳。 非卿一身一家，继代得福仙也。 使之不依经师，伪行妖妄，令人淫祀，天地星宿。 其罪反招减算夺寿，彼此俱被责罚。 夫正一之醮自有，仪出三元。 注：天师口诀告王长赵升曰：夫正减一之法，起自老君。 老君秘此法於天台，次经劫数岁后再出，号为后圣君，从天降下授吾，兼赐授科仪三会醮酒供养，如世之社会也，如军有设也。 皆须依时，失时不可，别日醮醮，即失科也。 可为天地三元。 一元得一日为社会，太上老君后圣君许以此日，礼集三元五行，六甲七星，九灵九精，二十八宿，三十五官，四十九官，百二十官将等，领天兵百千亿万，领星万像，是此日降会敌飨，皆以醉饱，得福於身家，并及下元五岳四渎。 社庙土地灵官得醉饱，主人受福。 若非此日，妄为醮会，或称本命，或称甲子，或言四时八节，皆为醮祭，用烧钱财，此入淫祀，闲鬼野神妄来就食，正一之神，星宿之神，都不来降。 唯身中箓神三将军，在身者得食，在天地者不得来降食。 即大怒，反损其身，何更欲求福德。 卿为吾之弟子，慎勿为此。 若不依永以失道，反损身家，慎之。
chunks.translated_text:
The ten thousand towns and people rejoice in peace, their merit piled high as mountains.
It is not merely for your single life or family that you inherit the blessings of immortality across generations.

If they act without reliance on scripture and masters, falsely practicing sorcery and deceit, they cause licentious worship of Heaven, Earth, and the starry hosts.
Their crimes will instead invite **retributive decrements**, forfeiting lifespan—both they and others will bear punishment.

The **Rectified-One’s** *jiào* rites have their own origins, their ceremonies drawn from the **Three Celestial Cycles**.

*(Note: The Celestial Master spoke in secret to King Chang Zhao Sheng: The law of **Rectified-One** originated with the **Venerable Lord**. The Venerable Lord concealed this law on the **Celestial Terrace**, then after countless eons, revealed it anew, calling himself the **Later Sage**, descending from Heaven to bestow it upon me. Alongside this, he granted the **Three Assemblies’** rites, offerings, and libations—like the world’s communal sacrifices, like a military encampment’s provisions. All must be performed at the proper time; if missed, it cannot be done. If held on another day, it is no longer the proper *jiào*—it becomes **Three Celestial Cycles** in vain.

On this day, one may gather a **Three Celestial Cycles** assembly, where the **Venerable Lord** and **Later Sage** permit it: the rites convene the **Three Celestial Cycles**, the **Five Phases**, the **Six Jia Lords**, the **Seven Stars**, the **Nine Spirits** and **Nine Essences**, the **Twenty-Eight Constellations**, the **Thirty-Five Officials**, the **Forty-Nine Officials**, and the **One Hundred Twenty Officers**—leading Heaven’s armies in the hundreds of billions, commanding the myriad star-forms. This is the day of their descent to feast, all sated and drunk, bestowing blessings upon the body and family, extending even to the **Lower Celestial Cycle’s** Five Sacred Peaks and Four Great Rivers. The **Community Altars**, **Temple Deities**, and **Spiritual Officials** are likewise sated and drunk, while the host receives blessings.

If not performed on this day, but held as a reckless *jiào* assembly—whether invoking one’s **natal destiny**, the **Six Jia**, or the **Four Seasons and Eight Nodes**—burning money and offerings, this falls under **licentious worship**. Wayward ghosts and wild spirits will come to gluttonously partake, while the **Rectified-One’s** deities and the **starry hosts** will not descend. Only the **three generals of the talismanic spirit** within the body may eat; those in Heaven and Earth cannot descend to feast. They will rage in fury, instead harming the body—how much more could one then seek virtue and blessings?

You are my disciple—be cautious and do not act thus. If you disregard this and stray from the Dao, you will harm your body and family. Be warned.)

chunks.original_text: 醮祭须依科行，万无不合天地水三官之神，使令得道之力。 若不依永招非横，即名阴灾。 注：灾祸之别名。 昔有人常行淫祀，得罪分明。 何更觅其功德。 卿须知之分明，教授正一三元法箓弟子，勿行淫妖，妄惑世人。 但依六甲之功，自然得道不失。 老君曰：此名六甲中十阴功也，修行之人得而宝秘勿泄，但依此修奉，自然得道。 六甲灵书阳功 又有《六甲灵书》，说阳功，有十篇。 故书之十诀，略记其名。 注：《太上老君传》中具说也。 一是广起因缘，集社众，造土木楼台观舍，积功千万，谓之阳功，不入阴数。 后圣君曰：此人结集社众，造此功夫，来生得为仕身，有财及高堂舍居，子孙富而无贵。 二修斋诵经，功积万遍，此名阳功，不入阴数。 君曰：来生聪明。 耳目清正，有善男女孝顺，有官。 三，劝人行善，令人布施，舍财千万，此亦阳功，不入阴数。 君曰：来生为人之长，为肉食人众之首，子孙继代为之。 四，行心舍力，广造土木，结架殿堂，严列山路，此亦畅功，不入阴数。 君曰：来生得为男身，有官职富有，奴婢人力驱使，二代不绝，身反即更不如前生，大道忌此心。 五，铸造锺像，功结神仙，像现世人一时之善，此亦阳功，不入阴数。 君曰：来生能歌唱，亦得端正身，而财食乏少。 六，能读咒辞，闲妄呼诵，扬声高叫，叱骂鬼神，虽救及人，亦是阳功。 君告天师曰：此功不得，平出於身，而虽救，为叱骂多，故来生少病，而乏子孙。 七，路川开井，施水及浆，此亦阳功。 虽施惠往人，合阴言功，为往来云，某乙造井。 君曰：此人后代子孙，受半阴功，自身阳功，托化为善惠，给急乏之人。 八，因官借力，救拔人罪，亦为阳功。 君曰：来生得福，或此生得报，善阳功也。 九，造建桥梁，往来通济，亦为阳功。 君曰：来生常得，往来人惠及。 十，受结受戒，清净心神，不以婚娶，栖山高上。 君曰：来生得道无为。 右此名十篇阳功，不入阴数。 昔高真上仙，皆以行阴功阴德，不比十行所十史为。 昔仙祖圣君，殷周之朝三为柱史，四为宰辅，事六十四天子，七百五十一年。 而西过关往胡国， 按传云：有妻八十四人，有子二百四人。 内传云云。 化胡王为佛仙，后上升为太平金阙帝晨后圣玄元上道君。 继代而行阴功，积而为阴德，善教无为之道，不假栖止山林之人。 久久高上，过去今身来生，受善报不失 金锁流珠引卷之十九竟 金锁流珠引卷之二十
chunks.translated_text:
The *jiào* rites must be performed strictly according to the prescribed methods, ensuring no failure to harmonize with the **Three Officials of Heaven, Earth, and Water**, thereby invoking the **Dao’s transformative power**.

If one disregards this and instead summons **unauthorized forces**, it becomes a **yin-disaster**—a term for calamity. *[Note: An alternative name for misfortune.]*
In the past, there were those who habitually engaged in licentious worship, their transgressions clear. How much more could they then seek virtue and blessings?

You must understand this clearly: As a disciple instructed in the **Rectified-One’s Three Primordial Talismans**, do not indulge in **licentious sorcery** or deceive the world. Only by adhering to the **Six Jia’s merit** will one naturally attain the Dao without deviation.

The **Venerable Lord** said: This is called the **"Ten Yin-Mercies of the Six Jia"**—those who practice must treasure and conceal it, for only by following this will one naturally attain the Dao.

---
**The *Six Jia Ling Shu* (Sacred Scriptures of the Six Jia) – Yang-Merits**
There is also the *Six Jia Ling Shu*, which expounds on **yang-merits**, comprising ten sections.
Here, the ten precepts are briefly recorded. *[Note: Fully elaborated in *The Transmission of the Venerable Lord*.]*

1. **Broadly gathering causes and conditions**, assembling congregations, constructing earthen and wooden pavilions and halls—accumulating merits numbering in the ten-thousands—this is called **yang-merit**, uncounted among the yin.
   The **Sage Sovereign** said: Such a person, in a future life, will become an official, possess wealth and grand halls, with prosperous descendants yet no noble status.

2. **Observing fasts and reciting scriptures**, accumulating merits numbering in the ten-thousands—this is called **yang-merit**, uncounted among the yin.
   The **Lord** said: In a future life, one will be endowed with wisdom, with clear and upright ears and eyes, having virtuous sons and daughters who are filial, and attaining official rank.

3. **Exhorting others to do good**, prompting almsgiving, and donating wealth numbering in the ten-thousands—this too is **yang-merit**, uncounted among the yin.
   The **Lord** said: In a future life, one will become a leader among people, the chief of those who consume flesh, with descendants inheriting this status across generations.

4. **Acting with sincere devotion and labor**, broadly constructing earthen and wooden structures, erecting frameworks for halls and temples, and rigorously clearing mountain paths—this too is **flourishing merit**, uncounted among the yin.
   The **Lord** said: In a future life, one will be reborn as a male, holding an official position with wealth, slaves, and servants at their command, with prosperity lasting two generations—yet afterward, one’s station will decline. The **Great Dao forbids such ambition**.

5. **Casting and crafting bells and statues**, completing the merit of becoming an immortal—where statues manifest the transient goodness of mortals—this too is **yang-merit**, uncounted among the yin.
   The **Lord** said: In a future life, one will be skilled in song and music, with a well-proportioned body, yet lacking in wealth and sustenance.

6. **Reciting incantations idly**, invoking them loudly and calling out to chastise ghosts and spirits—even if it saves a person—this is **yang-merit**.
   The **Lord** told the **Celestial Master**: Though this merit is not fully attained, it still emerges from the body, yet because the chastisement is excessive, in a future life one will suffer few illnesses but lack descendants.

7. **Digging wells along roads and rivers**, providing water and gruel—this too is **yang-merit**.
   Though this act benefits others, it aligns with **yin-speech of merit**, as it is said, *"So-and-so dug this well."*
   The **Lord** said: Such a person’s descendants will receive half of the yin-merit, while the individual attains yang-merit, transforming into benevolent deeds that aid those in urgent need.

8. **Leveraging official authority or borrowed strength to rescue others from罪**, this too is **yang-merit**.
   The **Lord** said: In a future life, one will receive blessings, or perhaps reap rewards in this very life—this is the merit of **auspicious yang**.

9. **Constructing bridges and causeways**, facilitating passage and transit—this too is **yang-merit**.
   The **Lord** said: In a future life, one will constantly benefit from the kindness of travelers.

10. **Receiving ordination and taking vows**, with a pure mind and spirit, abstaining from marriage, and dwelling in high mountains—this too is **yang-merit**.
   The **Lord** said: In a future life, one will attain the Dao of **non-action**.

---
These ten are called the **"Ten Yang-Merits"**, uncounted among the yin.
In the past, the **Highest True Ones** and **Ascended Immortals** all practiced **yin-merits and yin-virtues**, unlike the ten recorded histories of the ten yang-merits.

In antiquity, the **Divine Ancestor and Sage Sovereign** served as **Three Pillars of History** in the **Yin and Zhou dynasties**, as **Chancellor and Minister** for sixty-four sovereigns over seven hundred and fifty-one years. Then, crossing westward through the pass into the **Barbarian lands**, *[as transmitted:]* he had eighty-four wives and two hundred and forty children. *[As recorded in the Inner Transmission.]*
He transformed the **Barbarian King into a Buddha-Immortal**, later ascending to become the **Emperor of the Golden Gate of Great Peace, the Morning Star of the Supreme Dao, the Posterior Sage, and the Primordial Lord of the Mysterious Origin**. His successors continued practicing **yin-merits**, accumulating **yin-virtues**, and teaching the **Dao of Non-Action** without relying on those who dwell in mountains and forests.

Over time, ascending ever higher, past, present, and future lives—
**receiving unbroken blessings from virtuous deeds**—
*[End of the Nineteenth Volume of *The Golden Lock and Flowing Pearl*]*
*[Beginning of the Twentieth Volume of *The Golden Lock and Flowing Pearl*]*.

chunks.original_text: 中华总真大仙宰王方平张道陵赵升王长司命李仲甫茅盈许玉斧等系代撰述 中华仙人李淳风注 六甲七星步蹑为国战贼救度灾厄符法 老君曰：七星。 六甲之子也。 女子七人也。 或曾为皇后、皇妃、矫女等，各衣花服。 起自五姓六甲之后，盘古之初，即有七星见，为天人所见。 此即是元始之号，化大道之始生。 生乎浮天，回转於一日一夜周天，指地度数俱足，谓之七星。 主十天万民之死籍，又主生人疾厄，灾哀祸害，杀灭鬼神，乃前圣大道君所主部使也。 服以六甲符之功，合而使之。 六甲是七星之父母，故服六甲符者，图欲部使七星也。 昔太上老君服之长生，部使七星，随手所使。 又施存、李登、孟先、李夫人、西王母、麻姑、王方平，无不攻五行六甲，即使北斗得仙也。 缘北斗主杀，阴官所畏，鬼神受使。 不肯北斗使者，所手指之即死。 谓天关指处，皆有死损。 故上圣使令一日一夜，一周天遍也。 及配随衣着，故《流珠》谓之配衣。 昔上古大仙修行，不祭醮北斗。 小仙短见，即醮北斗。 谓何也。 为北斗是六阴之神，好杀不好生。 太上大道君恶见之，故以教太上老君，继代配为身衣使之，有二十四条， 具注於众事条中行事也。 具列於左。

The **Grand Sovereign of the Complete Perfection of the Chinese Realm**, namely **Zhang Daoling of the Peaceful Dao**, **Zhao Shengwang**, **Wang Chang**, **Commander Li Zhongfu**, **Master Mao Ying**, **Xu Yufu**, and others, were their descendants who compiled the scriptures.

The **Dao-Immortal Li Chunfeng** annotated the **Six Jiao and Seven Stars**—the talismans and methods for national defense, repelling bandits, and delivering from calamities and misfortunes.

**Lao Jun** said: *"Seven Stars—*
these are the children of the **Six Jiao**,
seven women in total.
Some were once **empresses**, **consorts**, or **Jiao women**,
each adorned in floral garments.
They emerged from the lineage of the **Five Clans and Six Jiao**,
since the time of **Pangu the Primordial**,
and were already visible as seven stars—
seen by both **heavenly beings and mortals**.
This is the very name of the **Primordial Origin**,
the manifestation of the **Great Dao** at its dawn.
Born in the **floating heavens**,
they revolve within the **one-day-one-night cosmic cycle**,
measuring the earth’s degrees with precision—
hence, they are called **Seven Stars**.
They oversee the **registers of death** for the **Ten Thousand Heavens and myriad people**,
and govern the illnesses and misfortunes of the living,
as well as calamities, grief, and harm.
They command and annihilate **ghosts and spirits**,
a division under the **Ancient Sage, the Great Dao Sovereign**.
When one invokes the **Six Jiao talisman’s power**,
combining it to deploy them,
the **Six Jiao** are the parents of the **Seven Stars**,
so those who wear the **Six Jiao talisman**
seek to command the **Seven Stars**.
In ancient times, the **Supreme Dao-Immortal** wore it for longevity,
commanding the **Seven Stars** at will.
He also bestowed upon **Cun, Li Deng, Meng Xian, Li FuRen, the Western Queen Mother, Ma Gu, and Wang Fangping**—
none of whom failed to subdue the **Five Phases and Six Jiao**,
thus enabling the **Northern Dipper to attain immortality**.
Since the **Northern Dipper governs death**,
it is feared by the **yin-officials**,
and **ghosts and spirits** submit to its command.
If the **Northern Dipper’s envoys** refuse to obey,
those it points to die instantly.
It is said that wherever the **Heavenly Gate** is directed,
there are deaths and injuries.
Thus, the **Supreme Sage** commands it to traverse the **cosmic cycle**—
once daily, once nocturnally.
And when paired with the corresponding garments,
the *Golden Lock and Flowing Pearl* refers to this as **paired garments**.
In ancient times, great **Dao-Immortals** practiced without offering sacrifices to the **Northern Dipper**.
Lesser **Dao-Immortals**, with limited vision,
would sacrifice to the **Northern Dipper**.
Why is this?
Because the **Northern Dipper** is a **god of the six yin-forces**,
fond of killing and averse to nurturing life.
The **Supreme Dao Sovereign** loathed its presence,
so he instructed the **Supreme Lao Jun**,
who in turn taught their successors to wear it as **garments of command**,
with twenty-four stipulations—
fully detailed in the **generalized conditions** for all affairs.
All are listed to the left.
